question:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) Fluconazole
C) Caspofungin
D) Prednisone
E) Surgical resection of the infiltrates
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> with a <fact2>history of asthma</fact2> visits her physician for worsening <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3>. She states that she feels as though her “<fact4>lungs are falling apart</fact4>,” noting that her <fact5>lung function has been steadily deteriorating</fact5>. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of <fact6>inhalers</fact6>, but she feels that they have not helped her control her <fact7>asthma exacerbations</fact7>. She has experienced <fact8>4 episodes of pneumonia</fact8> in the last <fact9>3 years</fact9> and often suffers from “<fact10>random</fact10>” bouts of <fact11>excessive coughing</fact11> and <fact12>wheezing</fact12>. When asked if her <fact13>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact13>, she states, “<fact14>Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it</fact14>.” She also states that her <fact15>coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with <fact16>fever</fact16>, <fact17>malaise</fact17>, and occasional <fact18>expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact18>. The <fact19>vital signs</fact19> include: <fact20>blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg</fact20>, <fact21>pulse 66/min</fact21>, <fact22>respiratory rate 26/min</fact22>, and <fact23>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact23>. On <fact24>physical exam</fact24>, the patient appears <fact25>frail-looking</fact25> and in <fact26>moderate respiratory distress</fact26>. <fact27>Auscultation</fact27> reveals <fact28>inspiratory crackles</fact28> in the <fact29>right lung base</fact29> and <fact30>coarse breath sounds</fact30> in the <fact31>bilateral upper lung lobes</fact31>. <fact32>Chest radiograph</fact32>, as shown below, reveals <fact33>atelectasis</fact33> in the <fact34>right lung base</fact34>. There are also <fact35>branched radiodensities</fact35> that the <fact36>radiologist</fact36> notes as being “<fact37>glove-finger shadows</fact37>” (noted by the <fact38>arrow</fact38> in the image). <fact39>Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE)</fact39> levels are <fact40>elevated</fact40>. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

Answer:
The patient's presentation of worsening <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3>, <fact8>4 episodes of pneumonia</fact8> in the last <fact9>3 years</fact9>, and <fact13>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact13> that is <fact14>greenish with specks of red in it</fact14> suggests a chronic and severe respiratory condition. The presence of <fact28>inspiratory crackles</fact28> in the <fact29>right lung base</fact29> and <fact30>coarse breath sounds</fact30> in the <fact31>bilateral upper lung lobes</fact31> further supports the diagnosis of a severe respiratory condition. The <fact32>chest radiograph</fact32> reveals <fact33>atelectasis</fact33> in the <fact34>right lung base</fact34> and <fact35>branched radiodensities</fact35> that are consistent with a fungal infection. The <fact39>serum immunoglobulin E (IgE)</fact39> levels are <fact40>elevated</fact40>, which is consistent with an allergic reaction. The patient's symptoms and radiographic findings are consistent with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), a severe and chronic respiratory condition caused by an allergic reaction to Aspergillus fumigatus. The most appropriate therapy for ABPA is <fact41>prednisone</fact41>, a corticosteroid that can help to reduce inflammation and prevent further damage to the lungs. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
An 81-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for memory issues. The patient’s son says he has difficulty remembering recent events and names. He says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his right eye, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. He had a left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago and a right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. His vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. His gait is hemiparetic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Alzheimer's disease
B) Frontotemporal dementia
C) Lewy body dementia
D) Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
E) Vascular dementia
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>81-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for <fact2>memory issues</fact2>. The patient’s son says he has difficulty remembering recent events and names. He says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his right eye, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for <fact3>diabetes mellitus type 2</fact3> and <fact4>hypertension</fact4>. He had a <fact5>left basal ganglia hemorrhage</fact5> 12 years ago and a <fact6>right middle cerebral artery infarction</fact6> 4 years ago. Current medications are <fact7>amlodipine</fact7>, <fact8>aspirin</fact8>, <fact9>clopidogrel</fact9>, <fact10>metformin</fact10>, <fact11>sitagliptin</fact11>, and <fact12>valsartan</fact12>. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of <fact13>urinary or fecal incontinence</fact13>. His vitals include: <fact14>blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg</fact14>, <fact15>pulse 78/min</fact15>, <fact16>respiratory rate 16/min</fact16>, and <fact17>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact17>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact18>alert and oriented</fact18>. He is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the <fact19>mini-mental status exam</fact19> is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. <fact20>Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side</fact20>. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with <fact21>exaggerated reflexes</fact21>. His <fact22>gait is hemiparetic</fact22>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
E) Vascular dementia

Explanation: 
The patient's symptoms of <fact2>memory issues</fact2> that have progressively worsened over the last several years, along with the recent acute worsening, suggest a neurodegenerative disorder. His medical history of <fact3>diabetes mellitus type 2</fact3> and <fact4>hypertension</fact4> increases his risk for vascular dementia. The patient's history of <fact5>left basal ganglia hemorrhage</fact5> 12 years ago and a <fact6>right middle cerebral artery infarction</fact6> 4 years ago further supports the diagnosis of vascular dementia. The patient's physical examination findings, including <fact20>Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side</fact20> and <fact21>exaggerated reflexes</fact21> on the right side, are consistent with a vascular cause of dementia. The <fact22>hemiparetic gait</fact22> also supports this diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is vascular dementia.

question:
A 14-year-old obese boy presents with severe right hip and knee pain. The patient says that he has been limping with mild pain for the past three weeks, but the pain acutely worsened today. He describes the pain as severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the right hip and knee joints. The patient denies recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history and no current medications. The patient is not sexually active and denies any alcohol, smoking or drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The right leg is externally rotated, and there is a limited range of motion in the right hip. Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint and 5 out of 5 elsewhere. There is no tenderness to palpation. No joint erythema, edema or effusion present. Sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. Plain radiographs of the right hip joint are significant for displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?
A) Reassess in 3 months
B) Immobilize the right knee with conservative treatment (i.e. rest, ice)
C) Intra-articular corticosteroid injection of the right hip joint
D) Pavlik harness
E) Surgical pinning of the right hip
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>14-year-old obese boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>severe right hip and knee pain</fact2>. The patient says that he has been <fact3>limping with mild pain for the past three weeks</fact3>, but the pain <fact4>acutely worsened today</fact4>. He describes the pain as <fact5>severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character</fact5>, and localized to the <fact6>right hip and knee joints</fact6>. The patient denies recent <fact7>illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past</fact7>. No significant <fact8>past medical history</fact8> and no current <fact9>medications</fact9>. The patient is not <fact10>sexually active</fact10> and denies any <fact11>alcohol, smoking or drug use</fact11>. The vital signs include: <fact12>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse 72/min</fact14>, <fact15>respiratory rate 15/min</fact15>, and <fact16>oxygen saturation 99% on room air</fact16>. Body mass index (BMI) is <fact17>32 kg/m2</fact17>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact18>alert and cooperative</fact18>. The <fact19>right leg is externally rotated</fact19>, and there is a <fact20>limited range of motion in the right hip</fact20>. Strength is <fact21>4 out of 5 at the right hip joint</fact21> and <fact22>5 out of 5 elsewhere</fact22>. There is no <fact23>tenderness to palpation</fact23>. No <fact24>joint erythema, edema or effusion present</fact24>. Sensation is <fact25>intact</fact25>. Deep tendon reflexes are <fact26>2+ bilaterally</fact26>. Laboratory tests are <fact27>unremarkable</fact27>. Plain radiographs of the <fact28>right hip joint</fact28> are significant for <fact29>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact29>. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?

Answer: The patient is a <fact1>14-year-old obese boy</fact1> with <fact2>severe right hip and knee pain</fact2> due to <fact29>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact29>, which is indicative of a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). This condition is more common in obese children and adolescents, particularly those with a <fact17>high BMI</fact17>. The most appropriate course of treatment for this patient is <fact30>surgical pinning of the right hip</fact30>. This is because SCFE is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent further displacement and potential complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Surgical pinning is the preferred treatment for SCFE to stabilize the femoral head and allow for proper healing [1]. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

Reference:
[1] Flynn, J. M., & Ganley, T. J. (2015). Slipped capital femoral epiphysis. Journal of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, 23(3), 147-155.

question:
A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?
A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41%
B) Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation
C) Hypokinetic wall of the left ventricle
D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
E) Decreased right atrial pressure

Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased <fact21>S1</fact21>, <fact22>S3 gallop</fact22>, and <fact23>grade 3/6 systolic murmur</fact23> best heard at the <fact24>left sternal border</fact24> in the <fact25>4th left intercostal space</fact25>. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of <fact26>ascites</fact26>. The <fact27>hepatic margin</fact27> is <fact28>3 cm below the right costal margin</fact28>. <fact29>Hepatojugular reflux</fact29> is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an <fact30>echocardiogram</fact30>?

Answer: The patient's presentation, including <fact3>leg swelling</fact3>, <fact4>right upper abdominal tenderness</fact4>, <fact9>fatigue</fact9>, and <fact10>syncope</fact10>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact17>pale and acrocyanotic</fact17>, <fact18>jugular vein distention</fact18>, <fact19>bilateral lower leg pitting edema</fact19>, <fact21>decreased S1</fact21>, <fact22>S3 gallop</fact22>, and <fact23>grade 3/6 systolic murmur</fact23>, are indicative of right-sided heart failure and tricuspid regurgitation. The presence of <fact26>ascites</fact26> and <fact27>hepatic margin</fact27> <fact28>3 cm below the right costal margin</fact28> further supports this diagnosis. The most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an <fact30>echocardiogram</fact30> is therefore <fact31>increased peak tricuspid regurgitation</fact31>.

question:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of worsening abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She reports nausea and vomiting and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), the pulse is 92/min, the respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows yellowish discoloration of her sclera. Her abdomen is tender in the right upper quadrant. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 432 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 196 U/L
Aspartate transaminase 207 U/L
Bilirubin  
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 2.7 mg/dL
Lipase 82 U/L
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole are initiated. After 12 hours, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), the pulse is 105/min, the respirations are 22/min, and the blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan
B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
D) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
E) Percutaneous cholecystostomy

<fact21>Direct 2.7 mg/dL</fact21>

Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows <fact23>dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts</fact23> and <fact24>multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder</fact24>. The <fact25>pancreas is not well visualized</fact25>. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with <fact26>ceftriaxone and metronidazole</fact26> are initiated. Her <fact29>temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact29>, the <fact30>pulse is 105/min</fact30>, the <fact31>respirations are 22/min</fact31>, and the <fact32>blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg</fact32>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 

Given the patient's presentation with worsening <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2> and <fact4>nausea and vomiting</fact4> after initiation of intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with <fact26>ceftriaxone and metronidazole</fact26>, the patient's condition has not improved, indicating a possible complication. The ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows <fact23>dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts</fact23> and <fact24>multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder</fact24>, which suggests a possible biliary obstruction or cholecystitis. The patient's <fact28>acute illness</fact28> and altered mental status may be due to sepsis or other complications related to the biliary obstruction.

The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform an <fact33>Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)</fact33> to assess the biliary system and potentially relieve the obstruction. ERCP is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for visualization of the biliary and pancreatic ducts and can be used to perform sphincterotomy, stone extraction, or stent placement to relieve obstruction.

The answer is {B}.

question:
A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with nausea, vomiting, fever, and pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen for the past 18 hours. He mentions that he has been experiencing intermittent episodes of pain at the same location over the last 3 months and that these episodes usually occur after a heavy meal and subside within 1 or 2 hours. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On examination of the abdomen, tenderness is present over the right upper quadrant; palpation over the area produces an inspiratory pause. An urgent bedside ultrasonogram shows a dilated common bile duct stone, but no stone in the common bile duct or in the gallbladder. Laboratory results show the following:
Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL (9.56 mmol/L)
Total leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 (17.4 x 10*9/L)
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Lymphocytes 25%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Platelet count 32,0000/mm3 (320 x 10*9/L)
Serum bilirubin (total) 1.8 mg/dL (30.78 μmol/L)
Serum bilirubin (direct) 1.1 mg/dL (18.81 μmol/L)
Serum alanine aminotransferase 96 U/L
Serum aspartate aminotransferase 88 U/L
Serum alkaline phosphatase
350 U/L (5.83 μkat/L)
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Urgent laparoscopic cholecystectomy
B) Medical management followed by elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy
C) Medical management followed by elective open cholecystectomy
D) Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ECRP)
E) Cholecystotomy

question:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:
Erythrocyte count 1/mm3
Leukocyte count 4,000/mm3
Glucose 59 mg/dl
Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L
Protein 3.8 g/dL
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?"
A) Bronchial adenocarcinoma
B) Mesothelioma
C) Nephrotic syndrome
D) Tuberculosis
E) Congestive heart failure
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>79-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>. During this period, she also has had a <fact3>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact3> and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has <fact4>congestive heart failure and hypertension</fact4>. Three months ago, she was in <fact5>India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding</fact5>. She worked as a <fact6>seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years</fact6>. She has <fact7>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years</fact7>. Her current medications include <fact8>enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol</fact8>. She appears <fact9>thin</fact9>. Her <fact10>temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 90/min</fact11>, <fact12>respirations are 25/min</fact12>, and <fact13>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact13>. <fact14>Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%</fact14>. There is <fact15>dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact15>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a <fact16>glucose level of 90 mg/dL</fact16>, <fact17>serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L</fact17>, and <fact18>serum protein of 6.3 g/dL</fact18>. An <fact19>x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion</fact19>. <fact20>Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid</fact20>. Analysis of the <fact21>pleural fluid aspirate shows:</fact21>
Erythrocyte count 1/mm3
Leukocyte count 4,000/mm3
Glucose 59 mg/dl
Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L
Protein 3.8 g/dL
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?

Answer: E) Congestive heart failure

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact2>2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact3>, and <fact15>dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact15> suggests a possible pulmonary issue. The patient's history of <fact4>congestive heart failure and hypertension</fact4> increases her risk for heart failure-related complications. The presence of a <fact19>x-ray of the chest showing nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion</fact19> and <fact20>Thoracentesis showing 250 ml of turbid fluid</fact20> further supports the presence of a pleural effusion. The analysis of the <fact21>pleural fluid aspirate</fact21> shows a high <fact22>protein level of 3.8 g/dL</fact22> and <fact23>lactate dehydrogenase of 248 U/L</fact23>, which are indicative of an exudative effusion. Given the patient's history of <fact4>congestive heart failure and hypertension</fact4> and the presence of an exudative effusion, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion is congestive heart failure.

question:
An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Initiate proton pump inhibitor
B) Obtain abdominal ultrasound
C) Reassurance and counseling on positioning
D) Recommend modification of mother’s diet
E) Switch to hydrolyzed formula
answer:

The patient has been <fact2>breastfed since birth</fact2>, and usually feeds for <fact3>30 minutes every 2-3 hours</fact3>. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about <fact4>two weeks ago</fact4> the patient began <fact5>regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds</fact5>. She reports that he seems <fact6>mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation</fact6> but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any <fact7>diarrhea</fact7>, <fact8>hematochezia</fact8>, or <fact9>family history of food allergies</fact9>. Her older son had a similar problem with <fact10>vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age</fact10>. Four weeks ago, the patient’s <fact11>height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively</fact11>. His <fact12>height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles</fact12>. On physical exam, the patient is <fact13>cooing in his mother’s lap</fact13> and <fact14>smiles reciprocally with her</fact14>. He <fact15>lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position</fact15>. His <fact16>abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended</fact16>. <fact17>Bowel sounds are normoactive</fact17>. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: C) Reassurance and counseling on positioning

Explanation: The patient is an <fact1>8-week-old male</fact1> presenting with <fact5>regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds</fact5>, which has been ongoing for <fact4>two weeks</fact4>. The mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which has reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. The patient's physical exam is unremarkable, with a <fact16>soft, non-tender and non-distended abdomen</fact16> and <fact17>normoactive bowel sounds</fact17>. The patient's growth parameters are stable, with a <fact12>height and weight in the 37th and 36th percentiles, respectively</fact12>. These findings suggest that the patient is likely experiencing a benign condition, such as <fact18>gastroesophageal reflux</fact18> or <fact19>positional reflux</fact19>. The best next step in management would be to provide <fact20>reassurance and counseling on positioning</fact20>, as recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) for infants with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or positional reflux.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last 6 months he slept a lot more than usual and lost 14.9 kg (33 lbs) without trying to lose weight. He also complains of chest pain and shortness of breath that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away 2 years ago in a fatal car accident. His blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg, the pulse is 90/min, the respiratory rate is 23/min, and the temperature is 38°C (100.5°F). On physical examination, he has pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities. There is a new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border. His head bobs with each heartbeat. There are small, painless, red macules on both palms. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. His laboratory results are shown below.
Hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 72 µm3
Platelet count 400,000/mm3
Leukocytes 6,000/mm3
Serum ferritin 8 ng/mL
Serum iron 27 µg/dL
Total iron-binding capacity 450 µg/dL
Colonoscopy with biopsy is later performed showing a neoplastic growth in the descending colon. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings?
A) Viridans streptococci
B) Treponema pallidum
C) Malignant colonic neoplasm
D) Collagen vascular disease
E) Group D streptococci
answer:

His <fact13>blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg</fact13>, the <fact14>pulse is 90/min</fact14>, the <fact15>respiratory rate is 23/min</fact15>, and the <fact16>temperature is 38°C (100.5°F)</fact16>. On physical examination, he has <fact17>pale mucous membranes</fact17>, <fact18>conjunctival hemorrhages</fact18>, and <fact19>petechiae on his lower extremities</fact19>. There is a new-onset <fact20>high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border</fact20>. His head <fact21>bobs with each heartbeat</fact21>. Answer: 
The patient's presentation of a <fact20>high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border</fact20> is indicative of aortic regurgitation. The presence of <fact21>a head that bobs with each heartbeat</fact21> further supports this diagnosis, as it is a characteristic sign of aortic regurgitation. Given the patient's <fact31>neoplastic growth in the descending colon</fact31>, the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings is a <fact33>malignant colonic neoplasm</fact33> causing aortic regurgitation through a paraneoplastic syndrome. The patient's <fact17>pale mucous membranes</fact17>, <fact18>conjunctival hemorrhages</fact18>, and <fact19>petechiae on his lower extremities</fact19> suggest a possible diagnosis of anemia and thrombocytopenia, which could be secondary to the malignancy. The patient's <fact26>high platelet count</fact26> could be secondary to a myeloproliferative disorder or a paraneoplastic syndrome. Therefore, the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings is a malignant colonic neoplasm causing aortic regurgitation through a paraneoplastic syndrome. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had dark brown emesis twice today. He has been having early satiety during this period. He has had progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?"
A) Inflammation and edema
B) Abnormal gastric rotation
C) Neoplastic growth
D) Scarring and fibrosis
E) Walled-off pancreatic fluid collection

question:
A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasingly severe abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting. His last bowel movement was yesterday and he has not passed flatus since then. He underwent appendectomy at the age of 39. He has psoriasis, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. He drinks two beers daily. He takes a topical corticosteroid, ramipril, metformin, and ibuprofen daily. He is 176 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 108 kg (240 lb); BMI is 35.4 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), respirations are 15/min, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 112/67 mm Hg. Examination shows thick, scaly, plaques over both elbows and knees. Abdominal examination shows three well-healed laparoscopic scars. The abdomen is distended and there are frequent, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows an empty rectum. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 44%
Leukocyte count 9,000/mm3
Platelet count 225,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 139 mEq/L
K+ 4.1 mEq/L
Cl− 101 mEq/L
HCO3− 26 mEq/L
Glucose 95 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 78 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 19 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 14 U/L
γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) 52 U/L (N=5–50 U/L)
Hemoglobin A1C 6.4%

A) Chronic inflammatory bowel disease
B) Obesity
C) Ibuprofen
D) History of abdominal surgery
E) Alcohol

Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is his <fact6>history of abdominal surgery</fact6>.

question:
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician to establish care. He recently moved to the area and has not been to a primary care physician for over 5 years. He has no history of serious illness, but has intermittent bilateral knee pain for which he takes 650 mg acetaminophen every other day. He is married with three children and is sexually active with his wife. During the past 10 years, he has unsuccessfully tried to lose weight. He has smoked one half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. About 2–3 times per week he has 1–2 glasses of wine with dinner. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 36.3 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. question:
A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and cough which she developed approx. 8 hours ago. 2 weeks ago she had a prophylactic ovariectomy because of a family history of ovarian cancer. She is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 1 hypertension, but she does not take her antihypertensives because she is not concerned about her blood pressure. Also, she has a history of opioid abuse. She takes metformin 1000 mg and aspirin 81 mg. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 22 years. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 155/80 mm Hg, heart rate 101/min, respiratory rate 31/min, and temperature 37.9℃ (100.2℉). Blood saturation on room air is 89%. On examination, the patient is dyspneic and acrocyanotic. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral rales over the lower lobes. A cardiac examination is significant for S2 accentuation best heard in the second intercostal space at the left sternal border and S3 presence. There is no leg edema. Neurological examination is within normal limits. Arterial blood gases analysis shows the following results:
pH 7.49
PaO2 58 mm Hg
PaCO2 30 mm Hg
HCO3-  22 mEq/L
Based on the given data, which of the following could cause respiratory failure in this patient?
A) Increased alveolar dead space due to absent perfusion of certain alveoli
B) Ischemia of the medullary respiratory center neurons
C) Alveolar fibrosis
D) Depression of the respiratory center via opioid receptors activation
E) Decreased V/Q due to bronchial obstruction

question:
A 30-year-old female presents to her primary care provider complaining of 4 days of fever, malaise, dyspnea, and productive cough and has recently developed pleuritic chest pain. Her past medical history is notable for asthma and takes albuterol as needed. She does not smoke but drinks alcohol socially. Her family history is notable for cystic fibrosis in her paternal uncle and interstitial lung disease in her paternal grandfather. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 21/min. Rales are noted in the right lower lung, and a chest radiograph demonstrates focal consolidation in the right lower lung lobe. After initiating the appropriate treatment, she agrees to take part in a study assessing the immune response to lung infections. A protein is identified in her serum that is thought to be elevated in response to her condition. An amino acid sequence at the carboxy terminus of the protein is isolated and a fluorescent marker is added to the sequence. This labeled sequence is subsequently added to a gel containing a protein isolated from the cell surface of the patient’s own neutrophils and macrophages and subsequently labeled with another fluorescent marker. The sequence binds strongly to this protein as evidenced by increased fluorescence in the gel. What process does this sequence typically undergo in immunocompetent individuals?
A) Affinity maturation
B) Random assortment
C) Random nucleotide addition
D) VDJ recombination
E) Isotype switching
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>30-year-old female</fact1> presents to her primary care provider complaining of <fact2>4 days of fever, malaise, dyspnea, and productive cough</fact2> and has recently developed <fact3>pleuritic chest pain</fact3>. Her past medical history is notable for <fact4>asthma</fact4> and takes <fact5>albuterol as needed</fact5>. She does not smoke but drinks <fact6>alcohol socially</fact6>. Her <fact7>family history</fact7> is notable for <fact8>cystic fibrosis in her paternal uncle</fact8> and <fact9>interstitial lung disease in her paternal grandfather</fact9>. Her <fact10>temperature is 101°F (38.3°C)</fact10>, <fact11>blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 110/min</fact12>, and <fact13>respirations are 21/min</fact13>. <fact14>Rales are noted in the right lower lung</fact14>, and a <fact15>chest radiograph demonstrates focal consolidation in the right lower lung lobe</fact15>. After initiating the appropriate treatment, she agrees to take part in a study assessing the <fact16>immune response to lung infections</fact16>. A <fact17>protein is identified in her serum that is thought to be elevated in response to her condition</fact17>. An <fact18>amino acid sequence at the carboxy terminus of the protein is isolated</fact18> and a <fact19>fluorescent marker is added to the sequence</fact19>. This <fact20>labeled sequence is subsequently added to a gel containing a protein isolated from the cell surface of the patient’s own <fact21>neutrophils and macrophages</fact21> and macrophages and subsequently labeled with another <fact22>fluorescent marker</fact22>. The sequence binds strongly to this protein as evidenced by increased <fact23>fluorescence in the gel</fact23>. What <fact24>process does this sequence typically undergo in immunocompetent individuals?</fact24>

Answer: The process that this sequence typically undergoes in immunocompetent individuals is <fact24>VDJ recombination</fact24>. This is evident from the fact that the <fact17>protein is identified in her serum that is thought to be elevated in response to her condition</fact17>, which suggests that the protein is an antibody. The <fact18>amino acid sequence at the carboxy terminus of the protein is isolated</fact18> and a <fact19>fluorescent marker is added to the sequence</fact19>, and then the labeled sequence is added to a gel containing a protein isolated from the cell surface of the patient’s own <fact21>neutrophils and macrophages</fact21>, which indicates that the sequence is being used to identify a specific antigen. This process is characteristic of VDJ recombination, which is the process by which the variable region of an antibody is formed through the recombination of V, D, and J gene segments. This process is essential for the development of a diverse repertoire of antibodies in immunocompetent individuals.

question:
A group of researchers from Italy conducted a case register study that included all patients from a city who had an International Classification of Diseases diagnosis and contacts with specialist psychiatric services over a 10-year period. Mortality was studied in relation to age, sex, diagnosis, care pattern, and registration interval. Standardized mortality ratios (SMRs) were calculated, with the overall SMR being 1.63 (lower when compared with studies that looked at hospitalized individuals). Men and those in younger age groups showed higher mortality rates (SMRs of 2.24 and 8.82, respectively), and mortality was also higher in the first year following registration (SMR = 2.32). Higher mortality was also found in patients with a diagnosis of alcohol and drug dependence (SMR = 3.87). The authors concluded that the overall mortality of psychiatric patients managed in a community-based setting was higher than expected; however, it was still lower than the mortality described in other psychiatric settings. The primary measure used in this study can be defined as which of the following?
A) The total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population
B) The number of deaths in a specific age group divided by a mid-year population in that age group
C) The total number of expected deaths divided by a standard population
D) The observed number of deaths divided by the expected number of deaths
E) The number of deaths from a certain disease in 1 year divided by the total number of deaths in 1 year
answer:
Reformatted Question: A group of researchers from Italy conducted a case register study that included all patients from a city who had an International Classification of Diseases diagnosis and contacts with specialist psychiatric services over a 10-year period. Mortality was studied in relation to age, sex, diagnosis, care pattern, and registration interval. Standardized mortality ratios (SMRs) were calculated, with the overall SMR being 1.63 (lower when compared with studies that looked at hospitalized individuals). Men and those in younger age groups showed higher mortality rates (SMRs of 2.24 and 8.82, respectively), and mortality was also higher in the first year following registration (SMR = 2.32). Higher mortality was also found in patients with a diagnosis of alcohol and drug dependence (SMR = 3.87). The authors concluded that the overall mortality of psychiatric patients managed in a community-based setting was higher than expected; however, it was still lower than the mortality described in other psychiatric settings. The primary measure used in this study can be defined as which of the following?

A) The total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population
B) The number of deaths in a specific age group divided by a mid-year population in that age group
C) The total number of expected deaths divided by a standard population
D) The observed number of deaths divided by the expected number of deaths
E) The number of deaths from a certain disease in 1 year divided by the total number of deaths in 1 year

Answer: D) The observed number of deaths divided by the expected number of deaths

Explanation: The primary measure used in this study is the standardized mortality ratio (SMR), which is a statistical measure used to compare the observed number of deaths in a population to the expected number of deaths based on a standard population. This is calculated by dividing the observed number of deaths by the expected number of deaths (option D). The SMR is a widely used measure in epidemiological studies to assess the mortality rates of different populations. In this study, the SMR was used to compare the mortality rates of psychiatric patients managed in a community-based setting to the expected mortality rates in a standard population.

question:
A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient has a past medical history of asthma and cocaine use. His current medications include albuterol and ibuprofen. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 70/35 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On initial trauma evaluation, his airway is intact and he is breathing spontaneously. The patient's dorsalis pedis and radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. His Glasgow Coma Scale is 9. Head to toe examination reveals instability of the pelvis when downwards force is applied. The patient is started on IV fluids and norepinephrine, and a pelvic binder is placed. The patient's vitals are measured again and his temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. A blood transfusion is started, and the patient is given hydromorphone. The patient suddenly becomes short of breath with notable bilateral wheezing with poor air movement. His blood pressure is 60/35 mmHg and pulse is 160/min. The patient is treated appropriately, intubated, stabilized, and transferred to the surgical intensive care unit. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient's history?
A) Hemolytic anemia and ataxia
B) Gum disease and poor wound healing
C) Irregularly irregular heart rhythm
D) Hepatitis C infection
E) Anti-A, B, or O antibodies in the serum
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient has a past medical history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> and <fact3>cocaine use</fact3>. His current medications include <fact4>albuterol</fact4> and <fact5>ibuprofen</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 70/35 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 150/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 19/min</fact9>, and <fact10>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact10>. On initial trauma evaluation, his <fact11>airway is intact</fact11> and he is breathing spontaneously. The patient's <fact12>dorsalis pedis and radial pulses are palpable bilaterally</fact12>. His <fact13>Glasgow Coma Scale is 9</fact13>. Head to toe examination reveals <fact14>instability of the pelvis when downwards force is applied</fact14>. The patient is started on <fact15>IV fluids</fact15> and <fact16>norepinephrine</fact16>, and a <fact17>pelvic binder is placed</fact17>. The patient's vitals are measured again and his <fact18>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact18>, <fact19>blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg</fact19>, <fact20>pulse is 150/min</fact20>, <fact21>respirations are 17/min</fact21>, and <fact22>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact22>. A <fact23>blood transfusion is started</fact23>, and the patient is given <fact24>hydromorphone</fact24>. The patient suddenly becomes <fact25>short of breath with notable bilateral wheezing with poor air movement</fact25>. His <fact26>blood pressure is 60/35 mmHg</fact26> and <fact27>pulse is 160/min</fact27>. The patient is treated appropriately, intubated, stabilized, and transferred to the surgical intensive care unit. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient's history? Options: (A) <fact28>Hemolytic anemia and ataxia</fact28> (B) <fact29>Gum disease and poor wound healing</fact29> (C) <fact30>Irregularly irregular heart rhythm</fact30> (D) <fact31>Hepatitis C infection</fact31> (E) <fact32>Anti-A, B, or O antibodies in the serum</fact32>

Answer: 
The patient had a history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> and <fact3>cocaine use</fact3>, and he was treated with <fact4>albuterol</fact4> and <fact5>ibuprofen</fact5>. The patient's sudden worsening after the administration of <fact24>hydromorphone</fact24> and the onset of <fact25>short of breath with notable bilateral wheezing with poor air movement</fact25> are indicative of an allergic reaction or anaphylaxis. The patient's history of <fact3>cocaine use</fact3> and the administration of <fact24>hydromorphone</fact24> are significant factors in this scenario. Cocaine can cause mast cell degranulation, leading to the release of histamine and other mediators, which can cause an allergic reaction or anaphylaxis. Hydromorphone is a common cause of anaphylaxis due to its opioid properties. Therefore, the most likely finding in this patient's history is related to a history of <fact3>cocaine use</fact3> and the administration of <fact24>hydromorphone</fact24>, which is not explicitly listed in the options provided. However, based on the information given, the closest answer would be (C) <fact30>Irregularly irregular heart rhythm</fact30>, as cocaine use is associated with irregularly irregular heart rhythms, but it is not the most direct answer.

question:
Five days after undergoing an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia while on a trip to Haiti, a 43-year-old woman develops low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. During the surgery, she received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. Three days after the surgery, she was stable enough to be transported back to the United States. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows moderate tenderness over the liver. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 12.0 g/dL
Leukocyte count 10,400 mm3
Segmented neutrophils 55%
Bands 1%
Eosinophils 13%
Lymphocytes 28%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 160,000 mm3
Serum
Alkaline phosphatase 102 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 760 U/L
Bilirubin
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 3.1 mg/dL
Anti-HAV IgG positive
Anti-HAV IgM negative
Anti-HBs positive
HBsAg negative
Anti-HCV antibodies negative
Abdominal ultrasonography shows an enlarged liver. A biopsy of the liver shows massive centrilobular necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?"
A) Adverse effect of anesthetic
B) Gram negative bacteria in the bloodstream
C) Trauma to the bile duct
D) Acalculous inflammation of the gallbladder
E) Excessive lysis of red blood cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>43-year-old woman</fact1> develops <fact2>low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain</fact2> five days after undergoing an emergency <fact3>appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia</fact3> while on a trip to <fact4>Haiti</fact4>. During the surgery, she received a transfusion of <fact5>1 unit of packed red blood cells</fact5>. Three days after the surgery, she was stable enough to be transported back to the <fact6>United States</fact6>. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her <fact7>temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 80/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg</fact9>. Examination shows <fact10>jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae</fact10>. Abdominal examination shows <fact11>moderate tenderness over the liver</fact11>. The <fact12>liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin</fact12>. Laboratory studies show: <fact13>Hemoglobin count 12.0 g/dL</fact13>, <fact14>Leukocyte count 10,400 mm3</fact14>, <fact15>Segmented neutrophils 55%</fact15>, <fact16>Bands 1%</fact16>, <fact17>Eosinophils 13%</fact17>, <fact18>Lymphocytes 28%</fact18>, <fact19>Monocytes 3%</fact19>, <fact20>Platelet count 160,000 mm3</fact20>, <fact21>Serum Alkaline phosphatase 102 U/L</fact21>, <fact22>Aspartate aminotransferase 760 U/L</fact22>, <fact23>Bilirubin Total 3.8 mg/dL</fact23>, <fact24>Direct 3.1 mg/dL</fact24>, <fact25>Anti-HAV IgG positive</fact25>, <fact26>Anti-HAV IgM negative</fact26>, <fact27>Anti-HBs positive</fact27>, <fact28>HBsAg negative</fact28>, <fact29>Anti-HCV antibodies negative</fact29>. Abdominal ultrasonography shows an <fact30>enlarged liver</fact30>. A biopsy of the liver shows <fact31>massive centrilobular necrosis</fact31>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

Answer: E) Excessive lysis of red blood cells

Explanation: The patient's condition is characterized by <fact2>low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain</fact2> five days after undergoing an emergency <fact3>appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia</fact3> while on a trip to <fact4>Haiti</fact4>. She received a transfusion of <fact5>1 unit of packed red blood cells</fact5> during the surgery. Laboratory studies show an elevated <fact22>Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 760 U/L</fact22>, which is indicative of liver injury. The <fact23>Bilirubin Total is 3.8 mg/dL</fact23> with a <fact24>Direct of 3.1 mg/dL</fact24>, suggesting a liver dysfunction. The patient's <fact7>temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F)</fact7> and <fact8>pulse is 80/min</fact8>, indicating a possible infection. However, the <fact25>Anti-HAV IgG is positive</fact25> and <fact26>Anti-HAV IgM is negative</fact26>, indicating immunity to Hepatitis A virus. The <fact27>Anti-HBs is positive</fact27> and <fact28>HBsAg is negative</fact28>, indicating immunity to Hepatitis B virus. The <fact29>Anti-HCV antibodies are negative</fact29>, indicating no evidence of Hepatitis C virus infection. The abdominal ultrasonography shows an <fact30>enlarged liver</fact30>, and the liver biopsy shows <fact31>massive centrilobular necrosis</fact31>. These findings suggest a liver injury, which is consistent with <fact32>hemolysis</fact32> due to the transfusion of <fact5>1 unit of packed red blood cells</fact5>. The patient's condition is most likely caused by <fact33>excessive lysis of red blood cells</fact33>, leading to liver dysfunction and the observed laboratory abnormalities.

question:
An unresponsive 92-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance and is quickly followed by his grand-daughter. Approx. 1 month ago, he had a radical prostatectomy, pelvic radiation, and several rounds of chemotherapy for aggressive prostate cancer in Nicaragua and was discharged from the hospital with a suprapelvic catheter and a plan for more chemotherapy. He was coming to the United States to spend time with some extended family. According to the grand-daughter his mental status was altered upon arrival and his health began to decline. She is not aware of his past medical status or medications. At the hospital, his blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, the pulse id 110/min, the respiratory rate is 21/min, and the temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F). On physical exam, the patient appears cachectic, drowsy, and only responds to questions by nodding his head. His heart rate is tachycardic with a regular rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter is red and swollen. The patient admitted to the hospital and stabilized and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The catheter tube produces no urine over 24 hours and only thick green-white puss can be expressed. The treatment team concludes this patient has urinary tract obstruction. What is the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction in this patient?
A) Renal biopsy
B) Ultrasound
C) Abdominal-pelvic CT scan
D) Blood analysis
E) Urine analysis
answer:

Approx. <fact2>1 month ago</fact2>, he had a <fact3>radical prostatectomy</fact3>, <fact4>pelvic radiation</fact4>, and several rounds of <fact5>chemotherapy</fact5> for <fact6>aggressive prostate cancer</fact6> in <fact7>Nicaragua</fact7> and was discharged from the hospital with a <fact8>suprapelvic catheter</fact8> and a plan for more <fact9>chemotherapy</fact9>. His <fact16>heart rate is tachycardic with a regular rhythm</fact16> and his <fact17>lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally</fact17>. The <fact18>cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter</fact18> is <fact19>red and swollen</fact19>. The patient admitted to the hospital and stabilized and started on <fact20>broad-spectrum antibiotics</fact20>. The catheter tube produces no urine over <fact21>24 hours</fact21> and only thick <fact22>green-white puss</fact22> can be expressed. The treatment team concludes this patient has <fact23>urinary tract obstruction</fact23>. What is the best method to evaluate <fact23>urinary tract obstruction</fact23> in this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation, the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction would be an <fact24>Abdominal-pelvic CT scan</fact24>. This is because the patient has a <fact8>suprapelvic catheter</fact8> with a <fact19>red and swollen</fact19> <fact18>cystotomy incision</fact18> and the catheter tube produces no urine over <fact21>24 hours</fact21> with only thick <fact22>green-white puss</fact22> expressed, indicating a possible obstruction. A CT scan would provide detailed images of the urinary tract, allowing for the identification of any potential obstructions, such as stones, tumors, or other abnormalities. This would be a more accurate method than a <fact25>Renal biopsy</fact25>, which would be more invasive and not as informative in this scenario. A <fact26>Urine analysis</fact26> may provide some information, but it would not be sufficient to evaluate the extent of the obstruction. A <fact27>blood analysis</fact27> may also provide some information, but it would not be directly related to the evaluation of urinary tract obstruction. An <fact28>Ultrasound</fact28> may provide some information, but it would not be as detailed as a CT scan in this scenario.

question:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of intermittent vertigo for the past 2 days. She complains of vomiting and complete hearing loss in her left ear. The patient believes she had an ear infection in the same ear but never sought out treatment. She has a past medical history of uterine fibroids. She takes mifepristone daily to reduce the size of the fibroids. Her blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg, the heart rate is 68/min, the respiratory rate is 12/min, and the temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). The patient appears pale and in mild distress. Otoscopy reveals a suppurative, erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane is observed to be immobile as confirmed by the pneumatoscope. Pure-tone audiometry testing reveals hearing loss across all frequencies in the left ear. Heart auscultation is without murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Nystagmus is positive to the right. MRI of the brain does not reveal a tumor or abscess. Her physician orders a complete blood count with differential and comprehensive metabolic panel, which show:
Hemoglobin 14.5 gm/dL
Hematocrit 43.2 %
White blood cells 14,500 /mm3
Platelets 312,000/mm3
Neutrophil 81.6%
Lymphocyte 15.2%
Monocyte 1.4%
Eosinophil 1.2%
Basophil 0.6%
Serum Na+ 138 mEq/L
K+ 4.3 mEq/L
Cl- 108 mmol/L
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic choice for this patient?
A) Ofloxacin
B) Cefepime
C) Cefotaxime
D) Amoxicillin
E) Cephalexin
answer:

question:
A 66-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence, difficulty urinating, incomplete voiding, and dull pain in the suprapubic region. She reports that she has not urinated for the past 2 days and that the urine leakage occurs during both day and night and is not associated with physical exertion. The medical history is significant for arterial hypertension and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for 8 years, and depression for 3 years. She is prescribed amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, metformin, and amitriptyline. Her weight is 75 kg (165 lb) and her height is 166 cm (5 ft 40 in). Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure, 120/80 mm Hg; heart rate, 91/min; respiratory rate, 13/min; and temperature, 36.4℃ (97.5℉). The physical examination reveals lower abdominal tenderness with a distended urinary bladder that is palpated in the suprapubic region. The neurological examination shows decreased Achilles reflexes bilaterally, and diminished fine touch and vibratory sensation. On gynecologic examination, the cervix was normally positioned, mobile, and without any visible lesions. Bulging of the posterior vaginal wall was noted. The adnexa were not palpable. An ultrasound examination showed an overdistended urinary bladder with no structural abnormalities. Which of the following is  the next step in managing this patient?
A) Installing a vaginal pessary
B) Bladder catheterization
C) Cystostomy
D) Prescribing bethanechol
E) Prescribing prostaglandin E2
answer:

She reports that she has not urinated for the past <fact6>2 days</fact6> and that the <fact7>urine leakage occurs during both day and night</fact7> and is not associated with physical exertion. The medical history is significant for <fact8>arterial hypertension</fact8> and <fact9>poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for 8 years</fact9>, and <fact10>depression for 3 years</fact10>. She is prescribed <fact11>amlodipine</fact11>, <fact12>valsartan</fact12>, <fact13>atorvastatin</fact13>, <fact14>metformin</fact14>, and <fact15>amitriptyline</fact15>. Her weight is <fact16>75 kg (165 lb)</fact16> and her height is <fact17>166 cm (5 ft 40 in)</fact17>. Her vital signs are as follows: <fact18>blood pressure, 120/80 mm Hg</fact18>; <fact19>heart rate, 91/min</fact19>; <fact20>respiratory rate, 13/min</fact20>; and <fact21>temperature, 36.4℃ (97.5℉)</fact21>. The physical examination reveals <fact22>lower abdominal tenderness</fact22> with a <fact23>distended urinary bladder</fact23> that is palpated in the <fact24>suprapubic region</fact24>. The neurological examination shows <fact25>decreased Achilles reflexes bilaterally</fact25>, and <fact26>diminished fine touch and vibratory sensation</fact26>. On <fact27>gynecologic examination</fact27>, the <fact28>cervix was normally positioned</fact28>, <fact29>mobile</fact29>, and without any visible lesions. <fact30>Bulging of the posterior vaginal wall</fact30> was noted. The <fact31>adnexa were not palpable</fact31>. An <fact32>ultrasound examination</fact32> showed an <fact33>overdistended urinary bladder</fact33> with no structural abnormalities. Which of the following is the next step in managing this patient?

Answer: B) Bladder catheterization

Explanation: The patient is experiencing <fact2>urinary incontinence</fact2>, <fact3>difficulty urinating</fact3>, <fact4>incomplete voiding</fact4>, and <fact5>dull pain in the suprapubic region</fact5>, which are all indicative of urinary retention. The patient has not urinated for the past <fact6>2 days</fact6> and has a <fact23>distended urinary bladder</fact23> that is palpated in the <fact24>suprapubic region</fact24>. The presence of <fact22>lower abdominal tenderness</fact22> further supports the diagnosis of urinary retention. Given the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings, the next step in managing this patient is to perform <fact34>bladder catheterization</fact34> to relieve the urinary retention and prevent further complications such as urinary tract infections or bladder rupture.

question:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to a productive cough. His cough has been increasing in frequency and severity over the course of 3 days, and his sputum production has increased in volume. The color of his sputum is yellow-green. He denies any chest pain or palpitations but has experienced worsening shortness of breath with exertion and at rest, which is above his baseline. He has not noticed any changes in his weight or edema in his lower extremities. He denies any recent history of long travel. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has been hospitalized four times for similar symptoms within the last year. He has smoked approximately 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 156/94 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 26/min with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has difficulty speaking, and there is asynchronous motion between the chest and abdomen with respiration. Wheezing is appreciated on pulmonary auscultation. An ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm. A chest radiograph is obtained, and he is administered supplemental oxygen. He is started on ipratropium, albuterol, and methylprednisolone. Which of the following should be added to this patient's treatment regimen?
A) Amoxicillin
B) Cefazolin
C) Ceftriaxone
D) Levofloxacin
E) Penicillin
answer:

His <fact3>cough has been increasing in frequency and severity</fact3> over the course of <fact4>3 days</fact4>, and his <fact5>sputum production has increased in volume</fact5>. The <fact6>color of his sputum is yellow-green</fact6>. He denies any <fact7>chest pain or palpitations</fact7> but has experienced worsening <fact8>shortness of breath with exertion and at rest</fact8>, which is above his baseline. He has not noticed any changes in his <fact9>weight or edema in his lower extremities</fact9>. He denies any recent history of <fact10>long travel</fact10>. Medical history is significant for <fact11>hypertension</fact11>, <fact12>hyperlipidemia</fact12>, and <fact13>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</fact13>. He has been hospitalized <fact14>four times for similar symptoms within the last year</fact14>. He has smoked approximately <fact15>1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years</fact15>. His <fact16>temperature is 102°F (38.9°C)</fact16>, <fact17>blood pressure is 156/94 mmHg</fact17>, <fact18>pulse is 101/min</fact18>, and <fact19>respirations are 26/min with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air</fact19>. On physical exam, the patient has <fact20>difficulty speaking</fact20>, and there is <fact21>asynchronous motion between the chest and abdomen with respiration</fact21>. <fact22>Wheezing is appreciated on pulmonary auscultation</fact22>. An <fact23>ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm</fact23>. A <fact24>chest radiograph is obtained</fact24>, and he is administered <fact25>supplemental oxygen</fact25>. He is started on <fact26>ipratropium</fact26>, <fact27>albuterol</fact27>, and <fact28>methylprednisolone</fact28>. Which of the following should be added to this patient's treatment regimen?

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact2>productive cough</fact2> with <fact5>sputum production increased in volume</fact5> and <fact6>yellow-green sputum color</fact6>, the patient is likely experiencing a respiratory infection. The patient's medical history of <fact13>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</fact13> and <fact15>smoking approximately 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years</fact15> increases his risk for bacterial infections. The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest that the patient is experiencing a bacterial respiratory infection, such as pneumonia. Given the patient's <fact3>cough has been increasing in frequency and severity</fact3> over the course of <fact4>3 days</fact4> and the presence of <fact5>sputum production has increased in volume</fact5>, empiric antibiotic therapy is warranted. The patient is already on <fact26>ipratropium</fact26>, <fact27>albuterol</fact27>, and <fact28>methylprednisolone</fact28>, which are typical treatments for acute exacerbations of COPD. However, these medications do not cover the patient's likely bacterial infection. Therefore, the most appropriate antibiotic to add to this patient's treatment regimen is <fact29>Levofloxacin</fact29>, which is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a wide range of bacteria, including those commonly causing respiratory infections in patients with COPD.

question:
A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks of gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal exam. Her last pregnancy was unremarkable and she gave birth to a healthy rhesus (RhD) positive girl. Her past medical history is notable for a blood transfusion after a car accident with a complex femur fracture about 3 years ago. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Examination shows that the uterus is at the umbilicus. Ultrasound examination reveals normal fetal heart rate, movement, and anatomy. Routine prenatal labs show the following:
Blood type A Rh-
Leukocyte count 11,000/mm3
Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL
Platelet count 345,000/mm3
Serum
Anti-D antibody screen Negative
Rubella IgM Negative
Rubella IgG Negative
Varicella IgM Negative
Varicella IgG Positive
STD panel Negative
Urine
Protein Trace
Culture No growth
Cervical cytology Normal
Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?"
A) Administer anti-D immunoglobulin now and repeat antibody screening shortly before delivery.
B) Repeat antibody screening at 28 weeks. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks and after delivery if the newborn is Rh(D) positive.
C) Repeat antibody screening at 28 weeks and administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks. No further management is needed.
D) No further screening is needed. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin shortly after delivery
E) No further management is needed
"
