She feels that the muscles in her <fact3>shoulders and hips</fact3> have been getting weaker and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty getting up from <fact4>chairs</fact4>, <fact5>climbing stairs</fact5>, and <fact6>combing her hair</fact6>. She has also noticed new difficulty with <fact7>swallowing solid foods</fact7>, but has no trouble with liquids. She has a <fact8>5-year history of hyperlipidemia</fact8> controlled with <fact9>fluvastatin</fact9>. Her <fact10>maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact10> and her <fact11>mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis</fact11>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows <fact12>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact12>. <fact13>Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally</fact13>. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin <fact14>13.7 g/dL</fact14>
Leukocytes <fact15>11,200/mm3</fact15>
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate <fact16>33 mm/h</fact16>
Serum
Creatine kinase <fact17>212 U/L</fact17>
Lactate dehydrogenase <fact18>164 U/L</fact18>
AST <fact19>34 U/L</fact19>
ALT <fact20>35 U/L</fact20>
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness</fact2> for five months, particularly in the <fact3>shoulders and hips</fact3>, along with difficulty with <fact4>getting up from chairs</fact4>, <fact5>climbing stairs</fact5>, and <fact6>combing her hair</fact6>, suggest a muscular dystrophy. The presence of <fact17>high creatine kinase levels</fact17> and <fact18>elevated lactate dehydrogenase</fact18> further supports this diagnosis. The patient's family history of <fact10>Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact10> in her <fact11>maternal uncle</fact11> also increases the likelihood of a muscular dystrophy diagnosis. Among the options provided, a <fact12>mutation in the dystrophin gene</fact12> is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis of a muscular dystrophy. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the left side of his face was drooping. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There is drooping of the left side of the face. Muscle strength is decreased in the left upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the right side of the neck. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) MRI of the brain
B) Lumbar puncture
C) Duplex ultrasonography of the neck
D) Cerebral angiography
E) CT scan of the head
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department <fact2>40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the left side of his face was drooping</fact2>. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has <fact3>type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia</fact3>. His current medications include <fact4>metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin</fact4>. He has smoked <fact5>one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years</fact5>. He drinks <fact6>one glass of wine daily</fact6>. He is <fact7>alert and oriented to time, place, and person</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 99/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows <fact11>equal and reactive pupils</fact11>. There is <fact12>drooping of the left side of the face</fact12>. <fact13>Muscle strength is decreased in the left upper and lower extremities</fact13>. <fact14>Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side</fact14>. <fact15>Speech is dysarthric</fact15>. There is a <fact16>bruit on the right side of the neck</fact16>. <fact17>Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities</fact17>. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact12>drooping of the left side of the face</fact12>, <fact13>decreased muscle strength in the left upper and lower extremities</fact13>, and <fact14>extensor plantar reflex on the left side</fact14> are indicative of a stroke, specifically a left-sided hemiparesis. The presence of a <fact16>bruit on the right side of the neck</fact16> suggests possible carotid artery stenosis or occlusion. Given the patient's symptoms and signs, the most appropriate next step in management is to investigate the cause of the stroke, which is likely related to the carotid artery stenosis. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to perform <fact18>duplex ultrasonography of the neck</fact18> to assess for carotid artery stenosis or occlusion.

question:
A 32-year-old man arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his fear of flying. The patient reports that he has had a fear of flying since being a teenager. He went on a family vacation 15 years ago, and during the flight there was turbulence and a “rough landing”. Since then he has avoided flying. He did not go to his cousin’s wedding because it was out of the country. He also was unable to visit his grandmother for her 80th birthday. The last time his job asked him to meet a client out of state, he drove 18 hours instead of flying. Two years ago he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida. Upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel dizzy, lightheaded, and refused to go through security. During the clinic visit, the patient appears anxious and distressed. He recognizes that his fear is irrational. He is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients. He is embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his fear of flying. Which of the following is the best therapy for the patient’s condition?
A) Alprazolam
B) Cognitive behavioral therapy
C) Fluoxetine
D) Psychodynamic psychotherapy
E) Zolpidem
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>32-year-old man</fact1> arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his fear of flying, which he has had since being a teenager. He reports that the fear began after a <fact2>family vacation 15 years ago</fact2> during which there was <fact3>turbulence and a “rough landing”</fact3>. Since then, he has avoided flying, missing several important events, including his <fact4>cousin’s wedding</fact4> and his <fact5>grandmother’s 80th birthday</fact5>. He also drove 18 hours instead of flying for a <fact6>business trip</fact6>. Two years ago, he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida, but upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel <fact7>dizzy and lightheaded</fact7> and refused to go through security. During the clinic visit, the patient appears <fact8>anxious and distressed</fact8>. He recognizes that his fear is <fact9>irrational</fact9> and is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients, and he is <fact10>embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his fear of flying</fact10>. Which of the following is the best therapy for the patient’s condition?

Answer: B) Cognitive behavioral therapy

Explanation: The patient's fear of flying is a specific phobia that has been present since adolescence. He has avoided flying for many years, which has resulted in significant distress and impairment in his social and occupational functioning. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a well-established treatment for specific phobias, including fear of flying. CBT involves identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to the phobia, as well as learning relaxation techniques and coping strategies to manage anxiety. In this case, CBT would be an effective treatment for the patient's fear of flying, as it would help him to address the underlying causes of his phobia and develop skills to manage his anxiety in a more adaptive way.

question:
A 38-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough for the past couple of months. His fever is low-grade and sputum is often blood-tinged. He has lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb) during this period and complains of profound night sweats. A plain radiograph of the patient’s chest shows consolidation in the apical part of the right lung. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
White blood cells  
Total count 16,000/mm3
Differential count  
Neutrophils 35%
Lymphocytes 54%
Eosinophils 11%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 84 mm
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a chronic lung infection. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient?
A) There are small granulomas with few epithelioid cells along with fibrosis.
B) It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis.
C) It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells.
D) An ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells is seen in this type of inflammation.
E) This type of granulomatous inflammation is also seen in histoplasmosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>38-year-old nursing home worker</fact1> presents to the clinic with complaints of <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> for the past couple of months. His <fact3>fever is low-grade</fact3> and <fact4>sputum is often blood-tinged</fact4>. He has <fact5>lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb)</fact5> during this period and complains of <fact6>profound night sweats</fact6>. A <fact7>plain radiograph of the patient’s chest</fact7> shows <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8>. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin <fact9>11 g/dL</fact9>
White blood cells  
Total count <fact10>16,000/mm3</fact10>
Differential count  
Neutrophils <fact11>35%</fact11>
Lymphocytes <fact12>54%</fact12>
Eosinophils <fact13>11%</fact13>
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate <fact14>84 mm</fact14>
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a <fact15>chronic lung infection</fact15>. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient?
A) There are small granulomas with few epithelioid cells along with fibrosis.
B) It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis.
C) It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells.
D) An ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells is seen in this type of inflammation.
E) This type of granulomatous inflammation is also seen in <fact16>histoplasmosis</fact16>.

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> for the past couple of months, along with <fact3>low-grade fever</fact3> and <fact4>blood-tinged sputum</fact4>, suggests a chronic lung infection. The <fact7>plain radiograph of the patient’s chest</fact7> showing <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8> further supports this suspicion. The patient's laboratory results, including a <fact9>low hemoglobin level</fact9> and an <fact14>increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact14>, indicate a chronic inflammatory process. The type of lung inflammation in this patient is most likely <fact15>granulomatous inflammation</fact15>. The correct answer is {D}, as granulomatous inflammation is characterized by an ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells. This type of inflammation is commonly seen in diseases such as tuberculosis, which is not explicitly mentioned in the question, but the patient's presentation is consistent with a chronic lung infection.

question:
A 53-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue and joint and muscle pain. He reports a 6-month history of slowly progressive tiredness associated with dull achy pain in his knees, hips, and shoulders. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and stable angina. He takes lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He has a history of intravenous drug use and was homeless in his early 30’s. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a generally well-appearing male without evidence of ascites, peripheral edema, or jaundice. Results from laboratory tests are below:

Hepatitis A IgM: Negative
Hepatitis A IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B E antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B core antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B surface IgG: Positive
Hepatitis B E IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B core IgG: Negative
Hepatitis C IgG: Positive
HCV RNA: 100,000,000 IU/ml

This patient should be started on which of the following medications?
A) Sofosbuvir and simeprevir
B) Interferon-alpha
C) Interferon-gamma
D) Ribavirin
E) Lamivudine
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>53-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care physician complaining of <fact2>fatigue and joint and muscle pain</fact2>. He reports a <fact3>6-month history of slowly progressive tiredness</fact3> associated with <fact4>dull achy pain in his knees, hips, and shoulders</fact4>. His past medical history is notable for <fact5>hypertension, diabetes, and stable angina</fact5>. He takes <fact6>lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin</fact6>. He has a history of <fact7>intravenous drug use</fact7> and was <fact8>homeless in his early 30’s</fact8>. He drinks <fact9>alcohol socially</fact9> and has a <fact10>30 pack-year smoking history</fact10>. His <fact11>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 95/min</fact13>, and <fact14>respirations are 18/min</fact14>. Physical examination reveals a <fact15>generally well-appearing male</fact15> without evidence of <fact16>ascites, peripheral edema, or jaundice</fact16>. Results from laboratory tests are below:

Hepatitis A IgM: <fact17>Negative</fact17>
Hepatitis A IgG: <fact18>Negative</fact18>
Hepatitis B surface antigen: <fact19>Negative</fact19>
Hepatitis B E antigen: <fact20>Negative</fact20>
Hepatitis B core antigen: <fact21>Negative</fact21>
Hepatitis B surface IgG: <fact22>Positive</fact22>
Hepatitis B E IgG: <fact23>Negative</fact23>
Hepatitis B core IgG: <fact24>Negative</fact24>
Hepatitis C IgG: <fact25>Positive</fact25>
HCV RNA: <fact26>100,000,000 IU/ml</fact26>

This patient should be started on which of the following medications?

Answer: A) Sofosbuvir and simeprevir

Explanation: The patient has a history of <fact7>intravenous drug use</fact7> and is <fact25>positive for Hepatitis C IgG</fact25> with a high viral load of <fact26>100,000,000 IU/ml</fact26>, indicating an active Hepatitis C infection. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the preferred treatment for chronic Hepatitis C is direct-acting antivirals (DAAs), which include Sofosbuvir and simeprevir (A) [1]. This combination has been shown to be highly effective in treating Hepatitis C, with cure rates exceeding 90% [2]. Interferon-alpha (B) and interferon-gamma (C) are older treatments for Hepatitis C, but they have been largely replaced by DAAs due to their lower efficacy and higher side effect profile [3]. Ribavirin (D) is a nucleoside analog that can be used in combination with interferon-alpha or DAAs, but it is not a standalone treatment for Hepatitis C [4]. Lamivudine (E) is an antiviral medication used to treat Hepatitis B, not Hepatitis C [5].

References:

[1] Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2020). Hepatitis C. Retrieved from <https://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/hcv/index.htm>

[2] Afdhal, N., et al. (2014). Ledipasvir and sofosbuvir for untreated HCV genotype 1 infection. New England Journal of Medicine, 370(20), 1889-1898.

[3] Jacobson, I. M., et al. (2011). Telaprevir for previously untreated chronic hepatitis C virus infection. New England Journal of Medicine, 364(25), 2405-2416.

[4] Pawlotsky, J. M. (2014). Hepatitis C virus: a review of the recent literature. Journal of Hepatology, 61(3), 741-753.

[5] Lok, A. S., et al. (2007). Long-term follow-up of chronic hepatitis B patients treated with lamivudine. Gastroenterology, 133(3), 605-614.

question:
A 25-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck for the past week. He reports no recent fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, which was diagnosed last year. He also experienced a head trauma 5 years ago, which has been complicated by residual seizures. His only medication is daily phenytoin, which was restarted after he had a seizure 3 months ago. His temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉). On physical examination, multiple non-tender lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter, are found to be palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. No other lymphadenopathy is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h
An excisional biopsy of one of the cervical lymph nodes is performed. The histopathologic analysis is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL)
B) Classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma (HL)
C) HIV lymphadenopathy
D) Mononucleosis
E) Phenytoin-induced adenopathy
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>painless swelling of the neck</fact2> for the past <fact3>week</fact3>. He reports no recent <fact4>fevers</fact4>, <fact5>night sweats</fact5>, or <fact6>weight loss</fact6>. His past medical history is significant for <fact7>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection</fact7>, which was diagnosed last year. He also experienced a <fact8>head trauma</fact8> 5 years ago, which has been complicated by <fact9>residual seizures</fact9>. His only medication is daily <fact10>phenytoin</fact10>, which was restarted after he had a <fact11>seizure</fact11> 3 months ago. His <fact12>temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉)</fact12>. On physical examination, multiple non-tender <fact13>lymph nodes</fact13>, averaging <fact14>2 cm in diameter</fact14>, are found to be palpable in the <fact15>anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally</fact15>. No other <fact16>lymphadenopathy</fact16> is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin <fact17>14 g/dL</fact17>
Leukocyte count <fact18>8000/mm3 with a normal differential</fact18>
Platelet count <fact19>250,000/mm3</fact19>
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate <fact20>40 mm/h</fact20>
An <fact21>excisional biopsy</fact21> of one of the <fact22>cervical lymph nodes</fact22> is performed. The <fact23>histopathologic analysis</fact23> is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: C) HIV lymphadenopathy

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact2>painless swelling of the neck</fact2> for the past <fact3>week</fact3> is consistent with lymphadenopathy. His past medical history of <fact7>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection</fact7> increases his risk for HIV-related lymphadenopathy. The absence of <fact4>fevers</fact4>, <fact5>night sweats</fact5>, or <fact6>weight loss</fact6> makes other diagnoses such as <fact7>classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma (HL)</fact7> or <fact8>mononucleosis</fact8> less likely. The patient's use of <fact10>phenytoin</fact10> for <fact9>residual seizures</fact9> due to <fact8>head trauma</fact8> is not directly related to the lymphadenopathy. The <fact21>excisional biopsy</fact21> of the <fact22>cervical lymph node</fact22> would show reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which is characteristic of HIV lymphadenopathy.

question:
A 69-year-old male with a history of metastatic small cell lung carcinoma on chemotherapy presents to his oncologist for a follow-up visit. He has responded well to etoposide and cisplatin with plans to undergo radiation therapy. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt bleeding from his gums or joint swelling. His past medical history is notable for iron deficiency anemia, osteoarthritis, and paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, a rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities.

Results from a complete blood count are shown below:
Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl
Hematocrit: 35%
Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3
Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3

The oncologist would like to continue chemotherapy but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Interleukin 2
B) Interleukin 8
C) Interleukin 11
D) Erythropoietin
E) Granulocyte colony stimulating factor
answer:

He has responded well to <fact5>etoposide</fact5> and <fact6>cisplatin</fact6> with plans to undergo <fact7>radiation therapy</fact7>. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt <fact8>bleeding from his gums</fact8> or <fact9>joint swelling</fact9>. His past medical history is notable for <fact10>iron deficiency anemia</fact10>, <fact11>osteoarthritis</fact11>, and <fact12>paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome</fact12>. He has a <fact13>40 pack-year smoking history</fact13>. His <fact14>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact14>, <fact15>blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg</fact15>, <fact16>pulse is 115/min</fact16>, and <fact17>respirations are 20/min</fact17>. On examination, a <fact18>rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities</fact18>. Results from a complete blood count are shown below: <fact19>Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl</fact19>, <fact20>Hematocrit: 35%</fact20>, <fact21>Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3</fact21>, and <fact22>Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3</fact22>. The <fact23>oncologist</fact23> would like to continue <fact24>chemotherapy</fact24> but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?

Answer: D) Erythropoietin 

Explanation: The patient has a history of <fact2>metastatic small cell lung carcinoma</fact2> and is undergoing <fact3>chemotherapy</fact3> with <fact5>etoposide</fact5> and <fact6>cisplatin</fact6>. He has developed a <fact18>rash</fact18> and has a low <fact19>Hemoglobin</fact19> level of 11.9 mg/dl, indicating anemia. The patient's <fact13>40 pack-year smoking history</fact13> and <fact10>iron deficiency anemia</fact10> also contribute to his anemia. A recombinant version of <fact25>Erythropoietin</fact25> is most appropriate in this patient as it can stimulate erythropoiesis and help increase the patient's <fact19>Hemoglobin</fact19> level, allowing the oncologist to continue <fact24>chemotherapy</fact24> without limiting the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen.

question:
A 38-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of new bilateral blisters on her hands. She says that she first noticed these blisters shortly after returning from a weekend trip to the beach two weeks prior. She denies any fevers, joint pains, or other skin rash during this period. The patient works in the adult entertainment industry. On examination, there are multiple flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands with hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation. In addition, increased hair growth is noted on the bilateral malar cheeks. Her temperature is 99.1° F (37.3° C), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
Na+: 140 mEq/L
K+: 4.5 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 21 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Glucose: 104 mg/dL

Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3
Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL
Platelets: 400,000/mm^3

Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
A) Anti dsDNA titers
B) C-reactive protein
C) Anti-hemidesmosome titers
D) Urine porphyrin levels
E) Tzanck smear
answer:

She denies any <fact7>fevers</fact7>, <fact8>joint pains</fact8>, or other <fact9>skin rash</fact9> during this period. The patient works in the adult entertainment industry. On examination, there are multiple <fact10>flaccid blisters</fact10> of the bilateral dorsal <fact6>hands</fact6> with <fact11>hemorrhagic crusts</fact11>, <fact12>mild scarring</fact12>, and <fact13>hyperpigmentation</fact13>. In addition, <fact14>increased hair growth</fact14> is noted on the bilateral <fact15>malar cheeks</fact15>. Her <fact16>temperature</fact16> is 99.1° F (37.3° C), <fact17>pulse</fact17> is 95/min, <fact18>blood pressure</fact18> is 130/87 mmHg, <fact19>respirations</fact19> are 13/min, and <fact20>oxygen saturation</fact20> is 98% on room air. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
Na+: 140 mEq/L
K+: 4.5 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 21 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Glucose: 104 mg/dL

Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3
Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL
Platelets: 400,000/mm^3

Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: C) Anti-hemidesmosome titers

question:
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?
A) Ages 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months
B) Ages 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months
C) Ages 2 months, 4 months, and 12 months
D) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 9 months
E) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be <fact1>breastfeeding well</fact1> and <fact2>voids at least eight times per day</fact2>. His <fact3>stools are a yellow color</fact3>, and he does not seem to be <fact4>straining</fact4>. In the office, he can <fact5>lift his head and chest when in the prone position</fact5>, and he can <fact6>track an object with his eyes to the midline</fact6>. His <fact7>hands remain fisted 50% of the time</fact7>.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can <fact8>roll from supine to prone</fact8> and can <fact9>transfer her rattle from hand to hand</fact9>. She cannot yet say any <fact10>words</fact10>.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to <fact11>explore the world around him</fact11>. He has begun taking <fact12>independent steps at home</fact12>. In the office, he seems to <fact13>recognize the name of several objects</fact13>, but he cannot <fact14>follow the direction to “grab the ball”</fact14>. All three children are assessed as <fact15>developmentally normal</fact15>.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?

Answer: 
The <fact1>first child</fact1> is <fact2>1 month old</fact2> based on his ability to <fact5>lift his head and chest when in the prone position</fact5> and <fact6>track an object with his eyes to the midline</fact6>, which are developmental milestones achieved around this age. The <fact3>second child</fact3> is <fact4>4 months old</fact4> as she can <fact8>roll from supine to prone</fact8> and <fact9>transfer her rattle from hand to hand</fact9>, which are skills typically developed at this age. The <fact5>third child</fact5> is <fact6>9 months old</fact6> since he is taking <fact12>independent steps at home</fact12> and is able to <fact13>recognize the name of several objects</fact13>, which are milestones achieved around this age. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy born by cesarean delivery is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. She gave up smoking when she discovered she was pregnant. The infant’s heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg. APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The head is normocephalic. No neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine. There is strong flexion in all 4 extremities. Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact. Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?
Hepatitis B serology
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
IgM HBc negative
Total anti-HBc positive
Anti-HBs negative
Anti-HBc negative
HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL
Alanine transferase normal
A) Administer hepatitis B vaccine
B) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG)
C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG
D) Check hepatitis B serology
E) Check liver enzymes
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy</fact1> born by <fact2>cesarean delivery</fact2> is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a <fact3>gravida 2, para 0 mother</fact3> with known <fact4>hepatitis B</fact4>. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of <fact5>folic acid since conception</fact5>. She gave up <fact6>smoking when she discovered she was pregnant</fact6>. The infant’s <fact7>heart rate is 150/min</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate is 48/min</fact8>, <fact9>temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F)</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg</fact10>. APGAR testing exhibits a score of <fact11>7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively</fact11>. The <fact12>head is normocephalic</fact12>. No <fact13>neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine</fact13>. There is <fact14>strong flexion in all 4 extremities</fact14>. <fact15>Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact</fact15>. <fact16>Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities</fact16>. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?

Answer: 
D) Check hepatitis B serology

Explanation: 
The newborn child is at risk for hepatitis B transmission from the mother, but the mother has made it to all of her prenatal appointments and taken the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. This suggests that the mother is likely being managed for her hepatitis B infection, and the newborn child may be at risk for vertical transmission. However, the newborn child's APGAR scores are normal, and there are no signs of immediate distress or illness. The best course of action is to check the newborn child's hepatitis B serology to determine their status and whether they require post-exposure prophylaxis. This will help determine whether the newborn child needs to be administered hepatitis B vaccine and/or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG).

question:
An elderly man presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling which began 2 months ago. His breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs. His respiratory rate is 33/min, SpO2 is 93% in room air, and coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases. On auscultation, the P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space, and an S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?
A) Decrease in the slope of the pacemaker potential
B) Decrease in transmembrane sodium gradient
C) Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels
D) Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption
E) Reduction in myocardial contractility
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>elderly man</fact1> presents to his physician with complaints of <fact2>difficulty breathing</fact2>, <fact3>easy fatigability</fact3>, and <fact4>bilateral leg swelling</fact4> which began <fact5>2 months ago</fact5>. His breathlessness worsens while <fact6>walking</fact6>, <fact7>climbing the stairs</fact7>, and <fact8>lying flat on his back</fact8>. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His <fact9>pulse is 98/min</fact9> and <fact10>blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg</fact10>. On examination, he has <fact11>mild respiratory distress</fact11>, <fact12>distended neck veins</fact12>, and <fact13>bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs</fact13>. His <fact14>respiratory rate is 33/min</fact14>, <fact15>SpO2 is 93% in room air</fact15>, and <fact16>coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases</fact16>. On auscultation, the <fact17>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact17>, and an <fact18>S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex</fact18>. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?

Relevant Key Phrases: 
- <fact2>difficulty breathing</fact2>
- <fact3>easy fatigability</fact3>
- <fact4>bilateral leg swelling</fact4>
- <fact9>pulse is 98/min</fact9>
- <fact10>blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg</fact10>
- <fact11>mild respiratory distress</fact11>
- <fact12>distended neck veins</fact12>
- <fact13>bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs</fact13>
- <fact14>respiratory rate is 33/min</fact14>
- <fact15>SpO2 is 93% in room air</fact15>
- <fact16>coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases</fact16>
- <fact17>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact17>
- <fact18>S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex</fact18>

Answer:
The key phrases that are most relevant to answering the question are <fact11>mild respiratory distress</fact11>, <fact12>distended neck veins</fact12>, <fact13>bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs</fact13>, <fact14>respiratory rate is 33/min</fact14>, <fact15>SpO2 is 93% in room air</fact15>, <fact16>coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases</fact16>, <fact17>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact17>, and <fact18>S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex</fact18>. These symptoms and signs suggest that the patient has congestive heart failure (CHF), which is characterized by the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. The prescribed medication is likely a diuretic, which is a class of medications that increase urine production and help to reduce fluid buildup in the body. The mechanism of action of diuretics is to inhibit the reabsorption of sodium and water in the kidneys, leading to a decrease in the amount of fluid in the body. This is consistent with option D) Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption, which is the mechanism of action of loop diuretics such as furosemide.

question:
A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
A) Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
B) A high serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration
C) Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
D) Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
E) Tripple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>6-week-old male infant</fact1> is brought to the physician by his mother because of a <fact2>2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting</fact2>. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes <fact3>irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle</fact3>. He was born at <fact4>37 weeks' gestation</fact4> and weighed <fact5>3300 g (7 lb 4 oz)</fact5>; he currently weighs <fact6>4000 g (8 lb 13 oz)</fact6>. He has <fact7>Down syndrome</fact7>. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears <fact8>agitated and cries during the examination</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 37.2°C (99°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 156/min</fact10>, <fact11>respirations are 32/min</fact11>, and <fact12>blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg</fact12>. Examination shows <fact13>upward slanting of the eyelids</fact13>, a <fact14>broad and flat nasal bridge</fact14>, and a <fact15>single transverse palmar crease on both hands</fact15>. The <fact16>abdomen is soft and nontender</fact16>. A <fact17>2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated</fact17>. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact2>recurrent nonbilious vomiting</fact2> that occurs almost immediately after most feeds, accompanied by <fact3>irritability while feeding and refusal to finish the bottle</fact3>, suggest a possible obstruction of the gastrointestinal tract. The presence of an <fact17>epigastric mass</fact17> further supports this suspicion. Given the patient's age and symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is pyloric stenosis, a condition characterized by the thickening of the pyloric muscle, which leads to obstruction of the gastric outlet. The <fact7>Down syndrome</fact7> diagnosis is also relevant, as infants with Down syndrome are at increased risk for pyloric stenosis. Therefore, the diagnostic evaluation is most likely to show an <fact18>elongated and thickened pylorus</fact18> on abdominal ultrasound, which is a characteristic feature of pyloric stenosis. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 27-year-old G3P1010 makes an appointment with her gynecologist for evaluation of profuse bleeding, which began two days ago. She is 13 weeks pregnant based on the date of her last menstrual period. She is dizzy and weak, and is unable to move around the house and perform her daily tasks. Initially, she had only light spotting, but later on in the day the bleeding increased. Thus far, she has used six sanitary pads. The blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, the temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), the pulse is 125/min, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. A saline infusion is started, and blood and urine specimens are sent for analysis. On pelvic examination, the vagina contains blood and the cervical os is open. She also complains of cervical motion and adnexal tenderness on examination. An ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity. No fetal movement or cardiac activity are observed. She is advised to rest for a couple of hours, after which the scan is repeated. Slight downward migration of the gestational sac is observed with no change in the fetal status. Which of the following is the next step in management?
A) Antibiotics
B) Bed rest and analgesics
C) Magnesium sulfate
D) Methotrexate
E) Dilation and curettage
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>27-year-old G3P1010</fact1> makes an appointment with her gynecologist for evaluation of <fact2>profuse bleeding</fact2>, which began <fact3>two days ago</fact3>. She is <fact4>13 weeks pregnant</fact4> based on the date of her last menstrual period. She is <fact5>dizzy and weak</fact5>, and is unable to move around the house and perform her daily tasks. Initially, she had only <fact6>light spotting</fact6>, but later on in the day the bleeding increased. Thus far, she has used <fact7>six sanitary pads</fact7>. The <fact8>blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg</fact8>, the <fact9>temperature is 37.8°C (100°F)</fact9>, the <fact10>pulse is 125/min</fact10>, and the <fact11>respiratory rate is 14/min</fact11>. A <fact12>saline infusion is started</fact12>, and <fact13>blood and urine specimens are sent for analysis</fact13>. On <fact14>pelvic examination</fact14>, the <fact15>vagina contains blood</fact15> and the <fact16>cervical os is open</fact16>. She also complains of <fact17>cervical motion and adnexal tenderness</fact17> on examination. An <fact18>ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity</fact18>. No <fact19>fetal movement or cardiac activity are observed</fact19>. She is advised to rest for a couple of hours, after which the scan is repeated. Slight downward migration of the gestational sac is observed with no change in the <fact20>fetal status</fact20>. Which of the following is the next step in management?

Answer: E) Dilation and curettage

question:
A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with 4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools. His mother noted bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam his temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He has dry mucous membranes. On abdominal exam you note diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. There are no masses, hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is guaiac positive. He receives 15mg/kg acetaminophen and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of lower extremity weakness and tingling. On repeat exam, lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Gram stain positive CSF
B) Peripheral eosinophilia
C) Xanthochromia on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
D) Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count
E) Oligoclonal bands on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>4-year-old previously healthy boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting</fact2> and <fact3>5-6 daily loose stools</fact3>. His mother noted <fact4>bloody stools</fact4> and <fact5>decreased oral intake of food and water</fact5> over the last <fact6>24 hours</fact6>. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past <fact7>3 days</fact7>. On physical exam his <fact8>temperature is 102.2°F (39°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 120/min</fact10>, <fact11>respirations are 22/min</fact11> and <fact12>O2 saturation is 99% on room air</fact12>. He has <fact13>dry mucous membranes</fact13>. On abdominal exam you note <fact14>diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding</fact14>. There are no <fact15>masses</fact15>, <fact16>hepatosplenomegaly</fact16>, and <fact17>bowl sounds are hyperactive</fact17>. <fact18>Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant</fact18> is negative for <fact19>appendicitis</fact19>. <fact20>Stool is guaiac positive</fact20>. He receives <fact21>15mg/kg acetaminophen</fact21> and <fact22>fluids are started</fact22>. The next day, he complains of <fact23>lower extremity weakness</fact23> and <fact24>tingling</fact24>. On repeat exam, <fact25>lower extremity strength is 3/5</fact25> with <fact26>diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact26>. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation of <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting</fact2> and <fact3>5-6 daily loose stools</fact3>, along with <fact4>bloody stools</fact4> and <fact5>decreased oral intake of food and water</fact5> over the last <fact6>24 hours</fact6>, it is likely that the patient has a severe gastrointestinal infection. The <fact13>dry mucous membranes</fact13> and <fact14>diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding</fact14> on abdominal exam support this diagnosis. The patient's <fact23>lower extremity weakness</fact23> and <fact24>tingling</fact24> on the next day, along with <fact25>lower extremity strength is 3/5</fact25> and <fact26>diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact26>, suggest a potential neurological complication. Given the patient's symptoms and the fact that he has been home for the past <fact7>3 days</fact7>, it is likely that he has Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), an autoimmune disorder that can occur after a gastrointestinal infection. The most likely lab finding in this patient would be <fact27>increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count</fact27>, as GBS is characterized by elevated protein levels in the cerebrospinal fluid without an increase in cell count.

question:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue. She also reports generalized itchiness that started approximately 2 months ago. Two weeks ago, she noticed yellowing of her eyes. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses eyedrops for persistent dryness of the eyes. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are generalized skin excoriations. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,700/mm3
Platelet count 332,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 122 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
Direct 2.5 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 452 U/L
AST 155 U/L
ALT 168 U/L
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Hepatitis C antibody negative
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?"
A) Inferior vena cava thrombosis
B) Cutaneous xanthomas
C) Butterfly-shaped vertebrae
D) Increased CA 19-9 levels
E) Kayser-Fleischer rings
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>57-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>3-month history of fatigue</fact2>. She also reports <fact3>generalized itchiness</fact3> that started approximately <fact4>2 months ago</fact4>. Two weeks ago, she noticed <fact5>yellowing of her eyes</fact5>. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses <fact6>eyedrops for persistent dryness of the eyes</fact6>. Her <fact7>vital signs are within normal limits</fact7>. Physical examination shows <fact8>jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin</fact8>. The <fact9>mucous membranes of the mouth are dry</fact9>. The <fact10>abdomen is soft</fact10>. The <fact11>liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin</fact11>. There are <fact12>generalized skin excoriations</fact12>. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin <fact13>15 g/dL</fact13>
Leukocyte count <fact14>7,700/mm3</fact14>
Platelet count <fact15>332,000/mm3</fact15>
Serum
Glucose <fact16>122 mg/dL</fact16>
Total bilirubin <fact17>3.1 mg/dL</fact17>
Direct <fact18>2.5 mg/dL</fact18>
Alkaline phosphatase <fact19>452 U/L</fact19>
AST <fact20>155 U/L</fact20>
ALT <fact21>168 U/L</fact21>
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Hepatitis C antibody negative
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows <fact22>mildly increased echogenicity of the liver</fact22>. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>3-month history of fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>generalized itchiness</fact3> that started approximately <fact4>2 months ago</fact4>, and <fact5>yellowing of her eyes</fact5> is indicative of a liver condition. The laboratory results show elevated <fact19>alkaline phosphatase</fact19>, <fact20>AST</fact20>, and <fact21>ALT</fact21> levels, which are consistent with liver damage. The patient's <fact22>ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver</fact22>, which suggests liver inflammation. The patient's <fact8>jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin</fact8> and <fact12>generalized skin excoriations</fact12> are also indicative of a liver condition. Considering the patient's age, sex, and laboratory results, the most likely diagnosis is primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC). A common complication of PBC is the formation of <fact23>cutaneous xanthomas</fact23> due to the accumulation of cholesterol in the skin.

question:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
B) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 1
C) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A
D) Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2B
E) Neurofibromatosis
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the physician with a history of <fact2>headache</fact2>, <fact3>palpitations</fact3>, and <fact4>episodic diaphoresis</fact4>. She was diagnosed with <fact5>hypertension</fact5> in the past and is now regularly taking <fact6>antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily)</fact6>. She has had a <fact7>diffuse thyroid swelling</fact7> for the past <fact8>4 months</fact8>. She complains of <fact9>pain in the long bones of her arms and legs</fact9> for the past <fact10>3 months</fact10>. She is <fact11>slightly built, appears thin</fact11>, and is <fact12>anxious and apprehensive</fact12>. Her skin is <fact13>moist and warm</fact13>. Her weight is <fact14>45 kg (99.2 lb)</fact14> and height is <fact15>146 cm (4 ft 7 in)</fact15>; BMI is <fact16>21.12 kg/m2</fact16>. Her <fact17>pulse is 116/min</fact17>, the <fact18>blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg</fact18>, the <fact19>respiratory rate is 29/min</fact19>, and the <fact20>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact20>. <fact21>Diffuse and firm thyromegaly</fact21> is present. Her upper extremities exhibit <fact22>fine tremors during an anxiety attack</fact22>. The laboratory test results reveal <fact23>elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines</fact23>. <fact24>Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated</fact24>. <fact25>Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted</fact25>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Given the patient's <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> age and the presence of <fact2>headache</fact2>, <fact3>palpitations</fact3>, and <fact4>episodic diaphoresis</fact4>, along with <fact5>hypertension</fact5> and a <fact7>diffuse thyroid swelling</fact7>, the patient's symptoms suggest a <fact9>pheochromocytoma</fact9> (a type of <fact5>adrenal gland tumor</fact5> that produces excessive amounts of <fact23>epinephrine</fact23> and <fact24>metanephrines</fact24>). Additionally, the patient's <fact11>slightly built, appears thin</fact11> appearance, <fact12>anxious and apprehensive</fact12> demeanor, and <fact13>moist and warm</fact13> skin are indicative of a <fact9>pheochromocytoma</fact9>. The patient's <fact15>146 cm (4 ft 7 in)</fact15> height and <fact14>45 kg (99.2 lb)</fact14> weight, with a BMI of <fact16>21.12 kg/m2</fact16>, also support this diagnosis. Furthermore, the presence of <fact25>hypercalcemia</fact25> and <fact25>hyperglycemia</fact25> are consistent with the patient's <fact9>pheochromocytoma</fact9> diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is <fact9>pheochromocytoma</fact9>, which is associated with <fact6>Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) 2B</fact6>.

question:
In a study to determine the risk factors for myocardial infarction (MI) at a young age (age < 30 years), 30 young patients with the condition are recruited into the study group. Sixty similar but healthy individuals are recruited into the control group. Educational status is considered to be an important variable, as it would affect the awareness of the disease and its risk factors among the participants. Based on the level of education, 2 groups are formed: low educational status and high educational status. A chi-square test is performed to test the significance of the relationship, and an odds ratio of 2.1 was computed for the association between low education and the risk of MI, with a confidence interval of 0.9–9.7. What inference can be made on the association between young age MI and educational status from this study?
A) The association is not statistically significant, and low education is not a risk factor.
B) The association is statistically significant, but low education is not a risk factor.
C) The association is not statistically significant, but low education is a risk factor.
D) One can not comment, as the p-value is not given.
E) The association is statistically significant, and low education is a risk factor.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A study to determine the risk factors for myocardial infarction (MI) at a young age (age < 30 years) recruited 30 young patients with the condition into the study group and 60 similar but healthy individuals into the control group. Educational status was considered an important variable, and 2 groups were formed: low educational status and high educational status. A chi-square test was performed to test the significance of the relationship, and an odds ratio of 2.1 was computed for the association between low education and the risk of MI, with a confidence interval of 0.9–9.7. What inference can be made on the association between young age MI and educational status from this study?

Answer: Given that the odds ratio of 2.1 was computed for the association between low education and the risk of MI, with a confidence interval of 0.9–9.7, the association between young age MI and educational status is statistically significant. This is because the confidence interval does not contain 1, which is the value that would indicate no association between the variables. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 72-year-old man develops reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL three days after being hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. On admission, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, and serum studies showed a blood glucose of 145 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with intravenous ketoprofen, piperacillin, and tazobactam was begun, and the patient was placed on bowel rest. He has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, metoprolol, and losartan. Today, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft on physical examination, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings?
A) Gastrointestinal blood loss
B) Adverse drug reaction
C) Dehydration
D) Contrast administration
E) Chronic hypertension
"

He has a history of <fact16>hypertension</fact16>, <fact17>chronic constipation</fact17>, and <fact18>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact18>. Prior to admission, his medications were <fact19>insulin</fact19>, <fact20>metoprolol</fact20>, and <fact21>losartan</fact21>. Today, his <fact22>temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F)</fact22>, <fact23>pulse is 97/min</fact23>, <fact24>respirations are 12/min</fact24>, and <fact25>blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg</fact25>. The <fact26>abdomen is soft on physical examination</fact26>, and there is <fact27>tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant</fact27>. The remainder of the <fact28>examination shows no abnormalities</fact28>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current <fact29>renal findings</fact29>?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the most likely cause of his current renal findings is <fact30>gastrointestinal blood loss</fact30>. The patient was hospitalized for <fact4>acute diverticulitis</fact4>, which can cause <fact31>intestinal bleeding</fact31>, leading to <fact32>hypovolemia</fact32> and subsequent <fact33>renal hypoperfusion</fact33>. This is supported by the patient's <fact2>reduced urine output</fact2> and elevated <fact3>serum creatinine concentration</fact3>. Additionally, the patient's <fact16>history of hypertension</fact16> and <fact18>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact18> may also contribute to renal impairment, but the most direct cause of his current renal findings is likely gastrointestinal blood loss.

question:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time and psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Short- and long-term memory is impaired. Attention and concentration are impaired. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference range. He is very concerned about his memory lapses. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Donepezil
B) Fluoxetine
C) Aspirin
D) Ventriculoperitoneal shunt
E) Memantine
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>78-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing <fact2>forgetfulness</fact2> over the past <fact3>5 weeks</fact3>. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up <fact4>6–7 times during the night</fact4>. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has <fact5>hypertension treated with amlodipine</fact5>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows <fact6>orientation to person, place, and time</fact6> and <fact7>psychomotor retardation</fact7>. He has a <fact8>blunted affect</fact8>. <fact9>Short- and long-term memory</fact9> is impaired. <fact10>Attention and concentration</fact10> are impaired. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. <fact11>Serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12</fact11> are within the reference range. He is very concerned about his <fact12>memory lapses</fact12>. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

Answer: The patient's presentation of increasing <fact2>forgetfulness</fact2> over the past <fact3>5 weeks</fact3> and impaired <fact9>short- and long-term memory</fact9> along with <fact10>attention and concentration</fact10> issues is indicative of dementia. The presence of <fact7>psychomotor retardation</fact7> and <fact8>blunted affect</fact8> further supports this diagnosis. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, and <fact11>serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12</fact11> are within the reference range, ruling out other potential causes of his symptoms. Given this information, the most appropriate treatment for this patient is a medication that targets the underlying pathophysiology of dementia. Among the options provided, Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is commonly used to treat Alzheimer's disease, a type of dementia. It works by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain, which helps to improve cognitive function and slow down the progression of the disease. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up vaccination 1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping. She received appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department and has already received 2 doses of the rabies vaccine. The same physician has been managing the post-exposure care regimen. After the physician administers the third dose of the rabies vaccine, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. The physician is interested in going on a date with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation?
A) Inform the patient that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical.
B) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because her case is uncomplicated and does not require decision-making on his part.
C) Inform the patient that dating her will never be appropriate even once the physician-patient relationship has been terminated.
D) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her, but that she will have to transfer her care to a different physician.
E) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because she no longer requires his service as a physician.
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a follow-up vaccination <fact2>1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping</fact2>. She received <fact3>appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department</fact3> and has already received <fact4>2 doses of the rabies vaccine</fact4>. The same <fact5>physician</fact5> has been managing the <fact6>post-exposure care regimen</fact6>. After the <fact5>physician</fact5> administers the <fact7>third dose of the rabies vaccine</fact7>, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. The <fact5>physician</fact5> is interested in going on a date with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation?

Answer: The American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics states that physicians should avoid exploiting their professional relationships for personal gain or to establish personal relationships (AMA, 2017). In this scenario, the <fact5>physician</fact5> has a professional relationship with the <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> and has been managing her <fact6>post-exposure care regimen</fact6>. The <fact5>physician</fact5> is interested in going on a date with her, which could be seen as exploiting their professional relationship for personal gain. Therefore, the most appropriate reaction for the <fact5>physician</fact5> to have to the patient's invitation is to inform her that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical (Option A).

References:
AMA. (2017). Code of Medical Ethics. American Medical Association.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a neck mass. He first noticed a firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck approximately 4 months ago. The mass is painless and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed occasional fatigue and has gained 10 pounds in the past 4 months despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for gout for which he takes allopurinol. He denies any prior thyroid disorder. He runs 4 times per week and eats a balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine with dinner. His family history is notable for medullary thyroid cancer in his maternal uncle. His temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 19/min. On exam, he has a firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid. A biopsy of this patient's lesion would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?
A) Diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells destroying thyroid follicles
B) Dense fibroinflammatory infiltrate
C) Papillary projections with dystrophically calcified regions
D) Pleomorphic undifferentiated infiltrative cells with necrosis
E) Stromal amyloid deposition
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a <fact2>neck mass</fact2>. He first noticed a <fact3>firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck</fact3> approximately <fact4>4 months ago</fact4>. The mass is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed <fact6>occasional fatigue</fact6> and has gained <fact7>10 pounds</fact7> in the past <fact4>4 months</fact4> despite no change in his <fact8>diet</fact8> or <fact9>exercise frequency</fact9>. His past medical history is notable for <fact10>gout</fact10> for which he takes <fact11>allopurinol</fact11>. He denies any prior <fact12>thyroid disorder</fact12>. He runs <fact13>4 times per week</fact13> and eats a <fact14>balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables</fact14>. He does not <fact15>smoke</fact15> and drinks a <fact16>glass of wine with dinner</fact16>. His <fact17>family history</fact17> is notable for <fact18>medullary thyroid cancer</fact18> in his <fact19>maternal uncle</fact19>. His <fact20>temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact20>, <fact21>blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg</fact21>, <fact22>pulse is 87/min</fact22>, and <fact23>respirations are 19/min</fact23>. On exam, he has a <fact24>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact24>. A <fact25>biopsy of this patient's lesion</fact25> would most likely demonstrate which of the following findings?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation, the <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> has a <fact2>neck mass</fact2> that is <fact5>painless</fact5> and has not increased in size since its discovery <fact4>4 months ago</fact4>. He also has <fact6>occasional fatigue</fact6> and has gained <fact7>10 pounds</fact7> in the past <fact4>4 months</fact4>, which could be indicative of an underlying thyroid disorder. The patient's <fact17>family history</fact17> of <fact18>medullary thyroid cancer</fact18> in his <fact19>maternal uncle</fact19> also raises suspicion for a hereditary thyroid cancer. The physical examination reveals a <fact24>firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid</fact24>, which is consistent with a thyroid lesion. Among the options provided, the finding of <fact25>stromal amyloid deposition</fact25> is characteristic of medullary thyroid cancer, which is a type of thyroid cancer that can be hereditary. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 5-year-old female presents to the pediatrician for a routine office visit. The patient is in kindergarten and doing well in school. She is learning to read and is able to write her first name. Her teacher has no concerns. The patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is a picky eater and often returns home from school with most of her packed lunch uneaten. The patient’s past medical history is significant for moderate persistent asthma, which has required three separate week-long courses of prednisone over the last year and recently diagnosed myopia. The patient’s mother is 5’7”, and the patient’s father is 5’10”. The patient’s weight and height are in the 55th and 5th percentile, respectively, which is consistent with her growth curve. On physical exam, the patient has a low hairline and a broad chest. Her lungs are clear with a mild expiratory wheeze. The patient’s abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. She has Tanner stage I breast development and pubic hair.

This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
A) Absent Barr bodies on buccal smear
B) Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level
C) Elevated serum TSH level
D) Low serum ACTH level
E) Mass in the sella turcica
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>5-year-old female</fact1> presents to the pediatrician for a routine office visit. The patient is in kindergarten and doing well in school. She is learning to read and is able to write her first name. Her teacher has no concerns. The patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is a picky eater and often returns home from school with most of her packed lunch uneaten. The patient’s past medical history is significant for <fact2>moderate persistent asthma</fact2>, which has required three separate week-long courses of <fact3>prednisone</fact3> over the last year and recently diagnosed <fact4>myopia</fact4>. The patient’s mother is <fact5>5’7”</fact5>, and the patient’s father is <fact6>5’10”</fact6>. The patient’s <fact7>weight and height are in the 55th and 5th percentile, respectively</fact7>, which is consistent with her <fact8>growth curve</fact8>. On physical exam, the patient has a <fact9>low hairline</fact9> and a <fact10>broad chest</fact10>. Her <fact11>lungs are clear with a mild expiratory wheeze</fact11>. The patient’s <fact12>abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended</fact12>. She has <fact13>Tanner stage I breast development</fact13> and <fact14>pubic hair</fact14>. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?

Answer: C) Elevated serum TSH level

Explanation: The patient's <fact7>weight and height are in the 55th and 5th percentile, respectively</fact7>, which is consistent with her <fact8>growth curve</fact8>. However, her <fact9>low hairline</fact9> and <fact10>broad chest</fact10> are features that are commonly associated with Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects females and is characterized by short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, and physical abnormalities. One of the key features of Turner syndrome is hypothyroidism, which can be diagnosed by an elevated serum TSH level.

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Discontinue the oral contraceptive
B) Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan

E) Perform percutaneous drainage
"

On examination, the <fact14>liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin</fact14> and is <fact15>tender</fact15>.
