<fact17>Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3</fact18>
<fact19>Segmented neutrophils 74%</fact19>
<fact20>Eosinophils 1%</fact20>
<fact21>Lymphocytes 20%</fact21>
<fact22>Monocytes 5%</fact22>
<fact23>Serum Glucose 79 mg/dL</fact23>
<fact24>Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL</fact24>
<fact25>Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL</fact25>
<fact26>Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L</fact26>
<fact27>AST 69 U/L</fact27>
<fact28>ALT 100 U/L</fact28>
A <fact29>right upper quadrant ultrasound</fact29> is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills</fact2> for <fact3>1 week</fact3>, along with <fact4>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact4> and <fact5>nausea</fact5>, the presence of <fact11>fever</fact11> and <fact12>increased pulse</fact12> suggest an infectious process. The <fact14>liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin</fact14> and is <fact15>tender</fact15>, which is indicative of liver involvement. Laboratory studies show elevated <fact18>leukocyte count</fact18> and <fact26>alkaline phosphatase</fact26>, which are indicative of an inflammatory process. The <fact29>right upper quadrant ultrasound</fact29> is mentioned but not described, so it is not possible to infer the findings from the ultrasound. However, based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is cholecystitis or cholangitis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to obtain a <fact30>hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan</fact30> to further evaluate the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

question:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police. He was found at a local celebration acting very strangely and was reported by other patrons of the event. The patient is very anxious and initially is hesitant to answer questions. He denies any substance use and states that he was just trying to have a good time. The patient's responses are slightly delayed and he seems to have difficulty processing his thoughts. The patient tells you he feels very anxious and asks for some medication to calm him down. The patient has a past medical history of psoriasis which is treated with topical steroids. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, you note an anxious young man. HEENT exam reveals a dry mouth and conjunctival injection. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with normal strength and sensation in his upper and lower extremities. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia, and pulmonary exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely intoxication in this patient?
A) Alcohol
B) Benzodiazepines
C) Marijuana
D) Cocaine
E) Phencyclidine
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by police. He was found at a local celebration acting very strangely and was reported by other patrons of the event. The patient is very anxious and initially is hesitant to answer questions. He denies any substance use and states that he was just trying to have a good time. The patient's responses are slightly delayed and he seems to have difficulty processing his thoughts. The patient tells you he feels very anxious and asks for some medication to calm him down. The patient has a past medical history of <fact2>psoriasis</fact2> which is treated with <fact3>topical steroids</fact3>. His <fact4>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 110/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 15/min</fact7>, and <fact8>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact8>. On physical exam, you note an <fact9>anxious young man</fact9>. <fact10>HEENT exam reveals a dry mouth and conjunctival injection</fact10>. <fact11>Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with normal strength and sensation in his upper and lower extremities</fact11>. <fact12>Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia</fact12>, and <fact13>pulmonary exam is within normal limits</fact13>. Which of the following is the most likely intoxication in this patient?

Answer: Based on the patient's symptoms and physical exam findings, the most likely intoxication is <fact14>phencyclidine (PCP)</fact14>. The patient's <fact9>anxious</fact9> and <fact10>agitated</fact10> behavior, <fact11>delayed responses</fact11>, and <fact12>difficulty processing thoughts</fact12> are consistent with PCP intoxication. Additionally, the patient's <fact13>dry mouth</fact13> and <fact14>conjunctival injection</fact14> are also consistent with PCP use. PCP is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause a range of symptoms, including anxiety, agitation, and hallucinations. It is often associated with a "bad trip" or a psychotic episode, which can be triggered by the patient's anxiety and agitation. The patient's <fact15>past medical history of psoriasis</fact15> and treatment with <fact16>topical steroids</fact16> does not provide any clues to the cause of his current symptoms. Therefore, the most likely intoxication in this patient is PCP. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of worries. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty in concentrating on her work. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more tired than usual. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping. While shopping, she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Administration of lithium
B) Interpersonal therapy
C) Psychodynamic psychotherapy
D) Cognitive behavioral therapy
E) Motivational interviewing
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of worries. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty in concentrating on her work. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more tired than usual. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping. While shopping, she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's behavior is indicative of <fact2>kleptomania</fact2>, a <fact3>psychiatric disorder</fact3> characterized by a recurring failure to resist urges to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or for their monetary value. This behavior is often associated with <fact4>feelings of relief</fact4> or <fact5>guilt</fact5> after the act. The most appropriate next step in management is to address the underlying psychological issues driving this behavior. Among the provided options, <fact6>cognitive behavioral therapy</fact6> is a <fact7>type of psychotherapy</fact7> that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors, which is particularly effective in treating <fact8>anxiety disorders</fact8> and <fact9>impulse control disorders</fact9> like kleptomania.

Answer: D) Cognitive behavioral therapy

question:

She is gravida 2 para 0 with a history of the same complaints in her last pregnancy which ended with a stillbirth at the 31st week. Her older sister had preeclampsia in both of her pregnancies. <fact20>Thrombocyte count 190,000/mm3</fact20>

Which of the following factors is a risk factor for this patient’s condition?

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a four month history of fatigue and weakness. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and does not take any medications. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL
AST: 9 U/L
ALT: 8 U/L
24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)
Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)
Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)

A <fact10>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact10> shows that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease. What is the best next step in management?

Answer: The best next step in management for this patient is to perform an <fact11>inferior petrosal sinus sampling</fact11> (option E). This is because the patient has a <fact12>high 24-hour urinary cortisol level</fact12> and a <fact13>non-suppressed serum cortisol level</fact13> after a <fact10>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact10>, indicating Cushing's syndrome. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is a diagnostic procedure used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent causes of Cushing's syndrome. It involves sampling the blood from the inferior petrosal sinus, which drains the pituitary gland, to measure the ACTH level. This can help to determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is a pituitary adenoma (ACTH-dependent) or an adrenal tumor (ACTH-independent).

question:
A 22-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist complaining of mood fluctuations. He is accompanied by his mother who reports that the patient recently experienced a 5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy. The patient admits to spending $2,000 of his parent’s money, without asking, on a down payment for a motorcycle. The episode resolved after 5 days, at which point the patient felt guilty and upset. The patient’s medical history is notable for multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty. The patient has a history of severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17 requiring four days in the intensive care unit. During that episode, he reported seeing monkeys in his hospital room. On exam, he is a well-appearing, cooperative male in no acute distress. He is alert and oriented with a normal affect. He states that he feels sad and guilty about what happens. He denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Bipolar I disorder
B) Bipolar II disorder
C) Cyclothymic disorder
D) Persistent depressive disorder
E) Schizoaffective disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>22-year-old man</fact1> presents to a <fact2>psychiatrist</fact2> complaining of <fact3>mood fluctuations</fact3>. He is accompanied by his <fact4>mother</fact4> who reports that the patient recently experienced a <fact5>5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy</fact5>. The patient admits to spending <fact6>$2,000 of his parent’s money</fact6>, without asking, on a down payment for a <fact7>motorcycle</fact7>. The episode resolved after <fact8>5 days</fact8>, at which point the patient felt <fact9>guilty and upset</fact9>. The patient’s medical history is notable for multiple <fact10>month-long episodes in the past 2 years</fact10> of feeling <fact11>sad</fact11>, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in his <fact12>hobbies</fact12>, and feeling constantly tired and guilty. The patient has a history of <fact13>severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17</fact13> requiring <fact14>four days in the intensive care unit</fact14>. During that episode, he reported seeing <fact15>monkeys in his hospital room</fact15>. On exam, he is a <fact16>well-appearing, cooperative male</fact16> in no acute distress. He is <fact17>alert and oriented with a normal affect</fact17>. He states that he feels <fact18>sad and guilty about what happens</fact18>. He denies <fact19>suicidal ideation</fact19>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: Based on the information provided, the patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Bipolar I disorder. The patient's history of <fact5>5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy</fact5> followed by <fact9>guilty and upset</fact9> is indicative of a manic episode, which is a hallmark of Bipolar I disorder. The patient's history of multiple <fact10>month-long episodes in the past 2 years</fact10> of feeling <fact11>sad</fact11> and <fact18>sad and guilty about what happens</fact18> suggests a history of depressive episodes, which is also consistent with Bipolar I disorder. The patient's history of <fact13>severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17</fact13> requiring <fact14>four days in the intensive care unit</fact14> and reporting <fact15>seeing monkeys in his hospital room</fact15> may be indicative of a psychotic episode, which is also consistent with Bipolar I disorder. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is Bipolar I disorder.

question:
A 22-year-old woman from a rural area who recently discovered she was pregnant is referred for a cardiology consultation due to cyanosis, dyspnea, and a cardiac murmur revealed at the initial prenatal visit. She is gravida 1, para 0 with an estimated gestational age of 19 weeks. She says that the murmur was found in her childhood, and the doctor at that time placed her under observation only. However, she has been lost to follow-up and has not had proper follow up in years. Currently, she complains of dizziness and occasional dyspnea on exertion which has gradually increased during her pregnancy. Prior to her pregnancy, she did not have any symptoms. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg, heart rate 81/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F). Her examination is significant for acrocyanosis and a fixed splitting of S2 and grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border. Which of the following physiological pregnancy changes is causing the change in this patient’s condition?
A) Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance
B) Increase in heart rate
C) Decrease in systemic vascular resistance
D) Increase in cardiac output
E) Increase in blood volume
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> from a <fact2>rural area</fact2> who recently discovered she was <fact3>pregnant</fact3> is referred for a <fact4>cardiology consultation</fact4> due to <fact5>cyanosis</fact5>, <fact6>dyspnea</fact6>, and a <fact7>cardiac murmur</fact7> revealed at the initial <fact8>prenatal visit</fact8>. She is <fact9>gravida 1, para 0</fact9> with an estimated <fact10>gestational age</fact10> of <fact11>19 weeks</fact11>. She says that the murmur was found in her <fact12>childhood</fact12>, and the doctor at that time placed her under <fact13>observation only</fact13>. However, she has been lost to <fact14>follow-up</fact14> and has not had proper <fact15>follow-up</fact15> in years. Currently, she complains of <fact16>dizziness</fact16> and occasional <fact17>dyspnea on exertion</fact17> which has gradually increased during her <fact18>pregnancy</fact18>. Prior to her <fact19>pregnancy</fact19>, she did not have any <fact20>symptoms</fact20>. The vital signs are as follows: <fact21>blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg</fact21>, <fact22>heart rate 81/min</fact22>, <fact23>respiratory rate 13/min</fact23>, and <fact24>temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact24>. Her examination is significant for <fact25>acrocyanosis</fact25> and a <fact26>fixed splitting of S2</fact26> and <fact27>grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur</fact27> best heard over the <fact28>left upper sternal border</fact28>. Which of the following physiological <fact29>pregnancy changes</fact29> is causing the change in this patient’s <fact30>condition</fact30>?

Answer: The physiological pregnancy change causing the change in this patient's condition is an <fact31>increase in cardiac output</fact31>. 

During pregnancy, the maternal cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to meet the increased metabolic demands of the fetus and the mother. One of the primary changes is an <fact32>increase in cardiac output</fact32> of approximately 40-50% above pre-pregnancy levels by the end of the third trimester [1]. This increase in cardiac output is necessary to meet the increased oxygen and nutrient demands of the fetus and to support the growth of the placenta. The increase in cardiac output is achieved through a combination of increases in heart rate and stroke volume [2]. 

In this patient, the <fact33>fixed splitting of S2</fact33> and the <fact34>grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur</fact34> best heard over the <fact35>left upper sternal border</fact35> suggest a possible patent foramen ovale or an atrial septal defect. The <fact36>increase in cardiac output</fact36> during pregnancy may exacerbate these conditions, leading to symptoms such as <fact37>cyanosis</fact37> and <fact38>dyspnea</fact38>. 

In conclusion, the physiological pregnancy change causing the change in this patient's condition is an <fact39>increase in cardiac output</fact39>.

References:
[1] American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. (2019). Cardiovascular disease in pregnancy. Obstetrics & Gynecology, 133(4), e137-e146.

[2] Clapp, J. F. (2002). Exercise during pregnancy. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, 186(5), 1177-1183.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents generalized abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. She has also had watery diarrhea for several days with no blood or pus in the stools. She is taking an over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication, which she cannot remember the name of, and drinking oral rehydration solution, which has helped a little. Her past medical history shows she was hospitalized 10 years ago for an appendectomy and 4 years ago for a fractured ulna following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs are pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, pupils are constricted. Extremities are pale and cold. The abdomen is soft but mildly, diffusely tender to palpation with a palpable bladder. No rebound or guarding. Fingerstick blood glucose is 124 mg/dL. Laboratory tests are pending. A urinary catheter is placed, and intravenous fluids are started. Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
A) Administer naloxone
B) Administer opioid analgesics
C) Scopolamine patch
D) Start dextrose infusion
E) Perform a gastric lavage
answer:

She has also had <fact4>watery diarrhea for several days</fact4> with no <fact5>blood or pus in the stools</fact5>. She is taking an over-the-counter <fact6>anti-diarrheal medication</fact6>, which she cannot remember the name of, and drinking <fact7>oral rehydration solution</fact7>, which has helped a little. Her past medical history shows she was hospitalized <fact8>10 years ago for an appendectomy</fact8> and <fact9>4 years ago for a fractured ulna following a motor vehicle accident</fact9>. Vital signs are <fact10>pulse is 104/min</fact10>, <fact11>blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg</fact11>, <fact12>respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing</fact12>, and <fact13>temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact13>. On physical examination, <fact14>pupils are constricted</fact14>. <fact15>Extremities are pale and cold</fact15>. The <fact16>abdomen is soft but mildly, diffusely tender to palpation</fact16> with a <fact17>palpable bladder</fact17>. No <fact18>rebound or guarding</fact18>. <fact19>Fingerstick blood glucose is 124 mg/dL</fact19>. Laboratory tests are pending. A <fact20>urinary catheter is placed</fact20>, and <fact21>intravenous fluids are started</fact21>. <fact22>Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities</fact22>. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Answer: A) Administer naloxone

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact2>generalized abdominal pain</fact2> and <fact3>vomiting for the past hour</fact3> in conjunction with <fact4>watery diarrhea for several days</fact4> with no <fact5>blood or pus in the stools</fact5> is suggestive of an opioid overdose. The presence of <fact14>pupils that are constricted</fact14> further supports this diagnosis. The patient's vital signs, including a <fact10>pulse of 104/min</fact10> and <fact11>blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg</fact11>, are within normal limits but the <fact12>respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing</fact12> indicates respiratory depression. The administration of <fact6>anti-diarrheal medication</fact6> may have contributed to the opioid overdose. Given the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings, the next best step in management is to administer <fact23>naloxone</fact23> to reverse the opioid overdose.

question:
A 62-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician by his wife who is concerned about the patient's frequent falls. Approximately 6 months ago, she started noticing that he was walking more slowly than usual. He has fallen more than 6 times in the past month, and she is worried that he will sustain a serious injury if he does not stop falling. The patient is a retired banking executive and was active as a triathlete until the age of 60. He does not smoke and drinks 2-3 alcoholic beverages per day. His family history is notable for normal pressure hydrocephalus in his mother and Alzheimer dementia in his father. His temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 131/81 mmHg, pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 19/min. On exam, his movements appear slowed and forced. He shuffles his feet when he walks. Tone is increased in his upper and lower extremities bilaterally. This patient's condition is most strongly associated with which of the following histologic findings on brain autopsy?
A) Accumulations of beta-pleated sheets
B) Atrophy of the caudate nucleus
C) Extracellular aggregates of amyloid beta
D) Intracellular inclusions of alpha-synuclein
E) Intracellular inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> is brought to his primary care physician by his wife who is concerned about the patient's frequent falls. Approximately 6 months ago, she started noticing that he was walking more slowly than usual. He has fallen more than 6 times in the past month, and she is worried that he will sustain a serious injury if he does not stop falling. The patient is a retired banking executive and was active as a triathlete until the age of 60. He does not smoke and drinks 2-3 alcoholic beverages per day. His family history is notable for <fact2>normal pressure hydrocephalus in his mother</fact2> and <fact3>Alzheimer dementia in his father</fact3>. His <fact4>temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 131/81 mmHg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 68/min</fact6>, and <fact7>respirations are 19/min</fact7>. On exam, his movements appear <fact8>slowed and forced</fact8>. He shuffles his feet when he walks. Tone is <fact9>increased in his upper and lower extremities bilaterally</fact9>. This patient's condition is most strongly associated with which of the following histologic findings on brain autopsy?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact8>slowed and forced movements</fact8> and <fact9>increased tone in his upper and lower extremities bilaterally</fact9> are indicative of Parkinson's disease. This condition is most strongly associated with <fact3>intracellular inclusions of alpha-synuclein</fact3>.

question:

The patient's cardiac exam demonstrates a normal rate and rhythm, and his pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation bilaterally. question:
A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department complaining of painful contractions occurring every 10 minutes for the past 2 hours, consistent with latent labor. She says she has not experienced vaginal discharge, bleeding, or fluid leakage, and is currently taking no medications. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 86/min, and temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). She has had little prenatal care and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sexually transmitted infections status is unknown. As part of the patient’s workup, she undergoes a series of rapid screening tests that result in the administration of zidovudine during delivery. The infant is also given zidovudine to reduce the risk of transmission. A confirmatory test is then performed in the mother to confirm the diagnosis of HIV. Which of the following is most true about the confirmatory test?
A) It determines the genotype of the virus
B) It is a Southwestern blot, identifying the presence of DNA-binding proteins
C) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of RNA
D) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of DNA
E) It is an HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay
answer:

She says she has not experienced <fact5>vaginal discharge</fact5>, <fact6>bleeding</fact6>, or <fact7>fluid leakage</fact7>, and is currently taking no medications. On physical examination, her <fact8>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact8>, <fact9>heart rate is 86/min</fact9>, and <fact10>temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F)</fact10>. She has had <fact11>little prenatal care</fact11> and uses <fact12>condoms inconsistently</fact12>. Her <fact13>sexually transmitted infections status is unknown</fact13>. As part of the patient’s workup, she undergoes a series of <fact14>rapid screening tests</fact14> that result in the administration of <fact15>zidovudine during delivery</fact15>. The <fact16>infant is also given zidovudine to reduce the risk of transmission</fact16>. A <fact17>confirmatory test</fact17> is then performed in the mother to confirm the diagnosis of <fact18>HIV</fact18>. Which of the following is most true about the <fact19>confirmatory test</fact19>? 

Options: (A) It determines the genotype of the virus (B) It is a <fact20>Southwestern blot</fact20>, identifying the presence of <fact21>DNA-binding proteins (C) It is a <fact22>Northern blot</fact22>, identifying the presence of <fact23>RNA (D) It is a <fact24>Northern blot</fact24>, identifying the presence of <fact25>DNA (E) It is an <fact26>HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay</fact26>

Answer: The confirmatory test is an <fact26>HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay</fact26>. This is because the patient has undergone a series of <fact14>rapid screening tests</fact14> that result in the administration of <fact15>zidovudine during delivery</fact15>, which is a treatment for HIV infection. The confirmatory test is then performed to confirm the diagnosis of HIV. The HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay is a type of confirmatory test that is used to confirm the diagnosis of HIV by detecting the presence of antibodies to HIV-1 and HIV-2.

question:
A 42-year-old man presents to establish care with a family physician after having progressively worsening back pain. He has recently migrated from Sweden and has not had any checkups in the last 3 years. He first started having back pain 3 years ago, but his pain has begun to be excruciating in the mornings. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels stiff every morning and this usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour. Both of his knees are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his hands for long periods of time due to joint pain and stiffness. His father and sister also have joint issues, and his mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis. He has been a smoker for 13 years. Upon physical examination, his wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
A) Testing for serum Ca and PTH
B) Calcium and Vitamin D prescription
C) Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies
D) Testing for serum ferritin
E) Synovial fluid aspiration
answer:

He has recently migrated from <fact3>Sweden</fact3> and has not had any checkups in the last <fact4>3 years</fact4>. He first started having <fact2>back pain</fact2> <fact5>3 years ago</fact5>, but his pain has begun to be <fact6>excruciating in the mornings</fact6>. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels <fact7>stiff every morning</fact7> and this usually lasts between <fact8>30 minutes and an hour</fact8>. Both of his <fact9>knees</fact9> are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his <fact10>hands</fact10> for long periods of time due to <fact11>joint pain and stiffness</fact11>. His <fact12>father and sister</fact12> also have <fact13>joint issues</fact13>, and his <fact14>mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis</fact14>. He has been a <fact15>smoker for 13 years</fact15>. Upon physical examination, his <fact16>wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints</fact16> are <fact17>warm and swollen</fact17>. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

Answer: Given the patient's presentation of <fact2>back pain</fact2> that is <fact6>excruciating in the mornings</fact6> and <fact7>stiff every morning</fact7>, along with <fact9>knee pain</fact9> and <fact10>hand pain</fact10> due to <fact11>joint pain and stiffness</fact11>, it is essential to consider the possibility of an inflammatory arthritis. The presence of <fact17>warm and swollen</fact17> joints in the <fact16>wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints</fact16> further supports this diagnosis. The patient's family history of <fact13>joint issues</fact13> and <fact14>osteoporosis</fact14> also increases the likelihood of an autoimmune disorder. The next best step in management would be to test for serum ESR and autoantibodies to help establish a diagnosis and guide further treatment. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who have all prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and leading to emotional distress and sleep disturbances. The physical examination is unremarkable, except for a mildly tender prostate, without masses or nodules. There are no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. Additionally to this health issue, you have also been following him for recurrent abdominal pain, periods of constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, with all test results within the normal range thus far. A summary of recent tests is shown in the following table:
Urine test
Sample White cells Culture
Mid-stream urine Negative Negative
Expressed prostatic secretion Positive Negative
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Benign prostatic hyperplasia
B) Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis
C) Acute prostatitis by Chlamydia trachomatis
D) Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli
E) Interstitial cystitis

A summary of recent tests is shown in the following table:
Urine test
Sample White cells Culture
Mid-stream urine <fact11>Negative</fact11> <fact12>Negative</fact12>
Expressed prostatic secretion <fact13>Positive</fact13> <fact14>Negative</fact14>
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: The patient presents with a <fact2>2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain</fact2>, <fact3>irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria)</fact3>, and <fact4>occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation</fact4>. The physical examination reveals a <fact7>mildly tender prostate</fact7>, which is indicative of prostatitis. The patient has been treated with <fact5>antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin</fact5>, with no improvement, suggesting a non-bacterial cause. The presence of <fact13>white cells in the expressed prostatic secretion</fact13> supports the diagnosis of prostatitis. The absence of <fact12>positive culture from the mid-stream urine</fact12> suggests that the infection is not a result of a urinary tract infection. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is <fact15>chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis</fact15>. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 55-year-old man presents with bloody nasal secretions and shortness of breath. He reports he has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) in the last two months with no changes in his diet. He has also been suffering from mild to moderate joint pain in the left knee for the last year. His past medical history is unremarkable. His vitals include: blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉), pulse 70/min, respiratory rate 14/min. Physical examination is significant for nasal ulcers. Diffuse crackles are present over all lobes of the lung bilaterally. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL
Hematocrit 37.7%
Leukocyte count 5500/mm3
Neutrophils 65%
Lymphocytes 30%
Monocytes 5%
Mean corpuscular volume 82.2 μm3
Platelet count 190,000/mm3

A) Anti-citrullinated protein antibodies
B) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

D) Anti-Ro
E) Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
