He reports he has lost <fact4>4 kg (8.8 lb)</fact4> in the last two months with no changes in his diet. He has also been suffering from <fact5>mild to moderate joint pain in the left knee</fact5> for the last year. His past medical history is unremarkable. His vitals include: <fact6>blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse 70/min</fact8>, <fact9>respiratory rate 14/min</fact9>. Physical examination is significant for <fact10>nasal ulcers</fact10>. Diffuse <fact11>crackles are present over all lobes of the lung bilaterally</fact11>. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
<fact12>Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Hematocrit 37.7%</fact13>
<fact14>Leukocyte count 5500/mm3</fact14>
<fact15>Neutrophils 65%</fact15>
<fact16>Lymphocytes 30%</fact16>
<fact17>Monocytes 5%</fact17>
<fact18>Mean corpuscular volume 82.2 μm3</fact18>
<fact19>Platelet count 190,000/mm3</fact19>
<fact20>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 35 mm/h</fact20>
<fact21>C-reactive protein 14 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Creatinine 3.09 mg/dL</fact22>
The patient is prescribed a <fact23>corticosteroid nasal spray</fact23> and <fact24>oral antibiotics</fact24> but returns in 2 weeks without any clinical improvement. Which of the following would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>bloody nasal secretions</fact2> and <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3> with <fact5>mild to moderate joint pain in the left knee</fact5> for the last year, along with <fact10>nasal ulcers</fact10> and diffuse <fact11>crackles are present over all lobes of the lung bilaterally</fact11>, suggests a systemic autoimmune disease. The laboratory findings of <fact12>Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL</fact12>, <fact13>Hematocrit 37.7%</fact13>, <fact20>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 35 mm/h</fact20>, and <fact21>C-reactive protein 14 mg/dL</fact21> further support this diagnosis. Among the options provided, <fact25>Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)</fact25> are most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient, as they are associated with vasculitis, which can present with symptoms such as <fact2>bloody nasal secretions</fact2>, <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3>, and <fact5>mild to moderate joint pain</fact5>. The presence of ANCA would indicate a diagnosis of Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), also known as Wegener's granulomatosis, which is a type of vasculitis that affects small- and medium-sized vessels. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past 3 months. Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years. She started having sexual intercourse with her boyfriend about 3 months ago. Six months ago she had a manic episode, which was treated with risperidone. Her mother has PCOS and her father has diabetes mellitus. She is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 27.02 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:
Prolactin 16 ng/mL
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 3.8 μU/mL
Follicle-stimulating hormone 6 mIU/mL
Luteinizing hormone 5.1 mIU/mL
Progesterone 0.8 ng/mL (follicular N <3; luteal N >3–5)
Testosterone 2.2 nmol/L (N <3.5)
A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?"
A) Uterine fibroids
B) Congenital defect of the Mullerian ducts
C) Purging behavior
D) Polycystic ovaries
E) Anovulation
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>15-year-old girl</fact1> comes to the physician because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past <fact2>3 months</fact2>. <fact3>Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow</fact3>. <fact4>Menarche was at the age of 14 years</fact4>. She started having <fact5>sexual intercourse with her boyfriend about 3 months ago</fact5>. <fact6>Six months ago she had a manic episode, which was treated with risperidone</fact6>. <fact7>Her mother has PCOS and her father has diabetes mellitus</fact7>. <fact8>She is very conscious of her weight and appearance</fact8>. <fact9>She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 27.02 kg/m2</fact9>. <fact10>Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg</fact10>. The <fact11>abdomen is soft and nontender</fact11>. <fact12>Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix</fact12>. <fact13>Serum hormone studies show:</fact13> Prolactin <fact14>16 ng/mL</fact14> Thyroid-stimulating hormone <fact15>3.8 μU/mL</fact15> Follicle-stimulating hormone <fact16>6 mIU/mL</fact16> Luteinizing hormone <fact17>5.1 mIU/mL</fact17> Progesterone <fact18>0.8 ng/mL (follicular N <3; luteal N >3–5)</fact18> Testosterone <fact19>2.2 nmol/L (N <3.5)</fact19> A <fact20>urine pregnancy test is negative</fact20>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact1>15-year-old girl</fact1> has not had menstrual bleeding for the past <fact2>3 months</fact2>. Her <fact4>menarche was at the age of 14 years</fact4>, and she had previously experienced irregular menses. She also has a <fact6>history of a manic episode treated with risperidone</fact6> and a family history of <fact7>PCOS and diabetes mellitus</fact7>. Her <fact8>concern about her weight and appearance</fact8> and the fact that she is <fact9>overweight</fact9> (BMI of 27.02 kg/m2) suggest that she may be experiencing symptoms related to eating disorders or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). However, her <fact13>serum hormone studies</fact13> show a <fact14>normal prolactin level</fact14>, <fact15>normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level</fact15>, <fact16>low follicle-stimulating hormone level</fact16>, <fact17>normal luteinizing hormone level</fact17>, <fact18>low progesterone level</fact18>, and <fact19>normal testosterone level</fact19>. These results do not support the diagnosis of PCOS, which is typically characterized by hyperandrogenism and ovulatory dysfunction. Therefore, the most likely cause of her symptoms is <fact20>anovulation</fact20>, which is a common cause of amenorrhea in adolescents.

question:
A 27-year-old college student presents to his physician for constant fatigue. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some occasional nausea and vomiting which has caused him to lose weight. The patient is a first year college student, drinks alcohol regularly, smokes marijuana, and has unprotected sex with multiple partners. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dL
AST: 85 U/L
ALT: 92 U/L

Urine
Color: Amber/brown
Marijuana: Positive
Amphetamines: Positive
Cocaine: Positive

The patient refuses an examination of his genitals. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?
A) CAGE questions
B) Direct influenza antigen
C) Uretheral swab and culture
D) Viral core antibody
E) Viral surface antibody
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>27-year-old college student</fact1> presents to his physician for <fact2>constant fatigue</fact2>. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some occasional <fact3>nausea and vomiting</fact3> which has caused him to lose weight. The patient is a first year college student, drinks alcohol regularly, <fact4>smokes marijuana</fact4>, and has <fact5>unprotected sex with multiple partners</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 17/min</fact9>, and <fact10>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact10>. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dL
AST: 85 U/L
ALT: 92 U/L

Urine
Color: Amber/brown
Marijuana: Positive
Amphetamines: Positive
Cocaine: Positive

The patient refuses an examination of his genitals. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?

Answer: 
Given the patient's refusal of a genital examination, it is crucial to choose a diagnostic test that does not require direct access to his genital area. The patient's laboratory values and urine analysis reveal abnormalities, including elevated liver enzymes and the presence of marijuana, amphetamines, and cocaine in the urine. These findings suggest substance use, which may be contributing to his symptoms of fatigue and nausea. However, the patient's refusal of a genital examination raises concerns about potential sexually transmitted infections (STIs). 

Considering the patient's behavior of having <fact5>unprotected sex with multiple partners</fact5> and the presence of STIs in the differential diagnosis, a diagnostic test that does not require a genital examination is necessary. 

The best diagnostic test among the provided options is the <fact11>Uretheral swab and culture</fact11>. This test allows for the collection of a sample from the urethra without requiring a genital examination, making it a suitable option for this patient.

question:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergent cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
A) “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”
B) “Losing a baby is difficult, but I'm sure next time it'll work out.”
C) “I'm sorry for your loss. Let's talk about how to move forward from here.”
D) “Losing a baby is difficult; but I see this every day, and I know you'll get through it.”
E) “I'm sorry for your loss. I can write you a prescription to help with your anxiety and grief.”
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation</fact1> comes to the emergency department for <fact2>abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding</fact2> for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her <fact3>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse is 102/min</fact4>, <fact5>respirations are 16/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg</fact6>. The <fact7>abdomen is nontender</fact7>, and regular <fact8>contractions are felt every 2 minutes</fact8>. The <fact9>uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation</fact9>. There is <fact10>blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs</fact10>. Ultrasound shows <fact11>complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus</fact11>. <fact12>Fetal heart tones are absent</fact12>. An <fact13>emergent cesarean delivery is performed</fact13>. Following the procedure, the patient becomes <fact14>tearful and distraught</fact14>. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

Answer: The most appropriate initial response by the physician is {A} "I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you."

This response acknowledges the patient's loss and shows empathy, which is essential in providing emotional support during a traumatic event. It is also a simple and direct statement that does not minimize the patient's feelings or provide false reassurance. Options B, C, and D are inappropriate because they either downplay the significance of the loss (B), focus on the physician's experience rather than the patient's feelings (D), or attempt to move the conversation forward too quickly (C). Option E is also inappropriate because it attempts to treat the patient's emotional response with a prescription, rather than acknowledging and validating her feelings.

question:
A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. There is blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line. Pelvic examination shows mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os and left adnexal tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
Platelet count 14,200/mm3
Fibrinogen 83 mg/mL (N = 200–430 mg/dL)
D-dimer 965 ng/mL (N < 500 ng/mL)
When phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90°C, a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain is identified. A blood culture is most likely to show which of the following?"
A) Coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci forming mauve-colored colonies on methicillin-containing agar
B) Encapsulated, gram-negative coccobacilli forming grey-colored colonies on charcoal blood agar
C) Spore-forming, gram-positive bacilli forming yellow colonies on casein agar
D) Lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar
E) Gamma-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci forming green colonies on vancomycin agar
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain</fact2>. Her <fact3>temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse is 126/min</fact4>, <fact5>respirations are 28/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg</fact6>. There is <fact7>blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line</fact7>. <fact8>Pelvic examination</fact8> shows <fact9>mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os</fact9> and <fact10>left adnexal tenderness</fact10>. Laboratory studies show: <fact11>Platelet count 14,200/mm³</fact11> <fact12>Fibrinogen 83 mg/mL</fact12> (N = 200–430 mg/dL) <fact13>D-dimer 965 ng/mL</fact13> (N < 500 ng/mL) When <fact14>phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90°C</fact14>, a <fact15>phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain</fact15> is identified. A blood culture is most likely to show which of the following?

Answer: 
D) Lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar 

The patient's presentation of <fact2>fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain</fact2> with <fact3>temperature of 39.1°C (102.3°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse of 126/min</fact4>, <fact5>respirations at 28/min</fact5>, and <fact6>low blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg</fact6> suggests sepsis. The presence of <fact7>blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line</fact7> and <fact9>mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os</fact9> during the <fact8>pelvic examination</fact8> point towards pelvic inflammatory disease. Laboratory results show a <fact11>low platelet count</fact11>, <fact12>decreased fibrinogen</fact12>, and <fact13>elevated D-dimer</fact13>, all of which are indicative of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The identification of a <fact15>phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain</fact15> when <fact14>phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90°C</fact14> suggests the presence of lipopolysaccharides typical of certain Gram-negative bacteria. Among the options provided, choice D describes a lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rod forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar, which is characteristic of Escherichia coli, a common pathogen responsible for severe infections leading to sepsis and DIC.

question:
A 16-year-old female presents to her physician’s office after noticing a round lump in her left breast 2 months ago. She reports that the lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses. It is otherwise painless, and the patient denies any discharge or skin changes. She has no past medical history but her grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use. On exam, the breasts appear symmetric and normal. A 3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?
A) This mass will likely require excision
B) This mass will decrease in size if the patient starts oral contraceptives
C) This mass slightly increases this patient’s risk of breast cancer in the future
D) This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
E) If this mass grows rapidly to greater than 5 cm, radiation and chemotherapy are indicated
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>16-year-old female</fact1> presents to her physician’s office after noticing a <fact2>round lump</fact2> in her left breast <fact3>2 months ago</fact3>. She reports that the lump seemed to <fact4>enlarge and became tender</fact4> just preceding her last <fact5>2 menses</fact5>. It is otherwise <fact6>painless</fact6>, and the patient denies any <fact7>discharge or skin changes</fact7>. She has no <fact8>past medical history</fact8> but her <fact9>grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast</fact9>. The patient is an <fact10>avid softball player</fact10> at her high school and denies <fact11>alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use</fact11>. On exam, the breasts appear <fact12>symmetric and normal</fact12>. A <fact13>3-cm round, mobile mass</fact13> is palpated in the <fact14>upper outer quadrant of the left breast</fact14>. There is <fact15>slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass</fact15>. There is no <fact16>axillary lymphadenopathy</fact16> on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation, the most likely outcome of her condition is that the mass will likely require excision. This is because the mass is described as a <fact2>round lump</fact2> that has <fact4>enlarged and become tender</fact4>, which is a common presentation of a breast mass. The fact that the mass is <fact13>3-cm round, mobile</fact13> and located in the <fact14>upper outer quadrant of the left breast</fact14> suggests that it may be a benign lesion, but further evaluation is needed to confirm this. The patient's age and family history of breast cancer also increase her risk of having a malignant lesion, so excision is likely the most appropriate course of action. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Agree to his wish for no further treatment
B) Begin paroxetine therapy
C) Involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents
D) Reassure the patient that he will feel better
E) Start outpatient psychotherapy
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A previously healthy <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation because of <fact2>loss of appetite</fact2>, <fact3>sleeplessness</fact3>, and <fact4>extreme irritability</fact4> for the past <fact5>3 weeks</fact5>. He was recently kicked off of the school's <fact6>football team</fact6> after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is <fact7>lonely</fact7>. He has not left his room for <fact8>2 days</fact8>, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a <fact9>constricted affect</fact9>. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “<fact10>end his misery</fact10>” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
The patient is a <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> with <fact2>loss of appetite</fact2>, <fact3>sleeplessness</fact3>, and <fact4>extreme irritability</fact4> for the past <fact5>3 weeks</fact5>, which are indicative of a depressive episode. His recent <fact6>dismissal from the school's football team</fact6> and <fact7>avoidance of social interactions</fact7> suggest that he may be experiencing feelings of <fact8>loneliness</fact8> and low self-esteem. The <fact9>constricted affect</fact9> observed during the mental status examination further supports the presence of depression. The patient's statement that he would be better off dead and his intention to use a firearm to <fact10>end his misery</fact10> indicate a high risk of <fact11>suicidal ideation</fact11>. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management is to ensure the patient's safety and prevent any potential harm. Involuntary hospitalization is necessary to provide the patient with the necessary treatment and support. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care provider after feeling sad and depressed for the past several months. His wife divorced him about 6 months ago and took the kids and moved out of state. Since then he has had difficulty waking up in the morning and getting to work on time. He takes some comfort in food and has gained about 9.1 kg (20 lb). He eats out several times a week and sometimes consumes 2 whole meals in one sitting. Other than this new obsession with eating large quantities of food and excess sleeping he no longer enjoys doing things he liked doing in the past. Besides eating and sleeping he is always excited to see his children and looks forward to their visits. He says it's the one thing keeping him going. Additionally, he does not feel like he has the same drive or focuses at work. He reports that he has no interest in hurting himself or others. His blood pressure is 119/81 mm Hg, pulse rate is 85/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and the temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). His physical exam is normal. What other symptom is most likely present in this patient?
A) Leaden paralysis
B) Depressive symptoms that are worse in the morning
C) Psychotic features
D) Stereotypies
E) Mania
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider after feeling <fact2>sad and depressed</fact2> for the past several months. His wife divorced him about <fact3>6 months ago</fact3> and took the kids and moved out of state. Since then he has had difficulty waking up in the morning and getting to work on time. He takes some comfort in food and has gained about <fact4>9.1 kg (20 lb)</fact4>. He eats out several times a week and sometimes consumes <fact5>2 whole meals in one sitting</fact5>. Other than this new obsession with eating large quantities of food and excess sleeping he no longer enjoys doing things he liked doing in the past. Besides eating and sleeping he is always excited to see his children and looks forward to their visits. He says it's the one thing keeping him going. Additionally, he does not feel like he has the same drive or focuses at work. He reports that he has no interest in hurting himself or others. His <fact6>blood pressure is 119/81 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse rate is 85/min</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate is 12/min</fact8>, and the <fact9>temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F)</fact9>. His <fact10>physical exam is normal</fact10>. What other symptom is most likely present in this patient?

Answer: Based on the information provided, the patient is experiencing symptoms of depression, including <fact2>feeling sad and depressed</fact2> for several months, difficulty waking up in the morning, and loss of interest in activities he previously enjoyed. He also reports <fact11>excessive eating</fact11> and <fact12>excessive sleeping</fact12>, which are common symptoms of depression, particularly in the context of a significant life change such as a divorce. The presence of <fact13>excessive eating</fact13> and <fact14>excessive sleeping</fact14> is consistent with a diagnosis of atypical depression, which is characterized by the presence of these symptoms. Therefore, the most likely additional symptom present in this patient is <fact15>leaden paralysis</fact15>, which is a common feature of atypical depression. Leaden paralysis is characterized by a feeling of heaviness or leadenness in the arms or legs, which is often accompanied by fatigue and a lack of energy. This symptom is consistent with the patient's report of feeling <fact2>exhausted</fact2> and lacking <fact16>drive or focus</fact16> at work.

question:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty discarding items in her home. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little emotional or monetary value. She reports that there has been no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg. On mental status examination, she is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. Her mood is depressed; her speech is organized, logical, and coherent; and there are no psychotic symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Atomoxetine
B) Fluoxetine
C) Lamotrigine
D) Buspirone
E) Methylphenidate
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>difficulty discarding items in her home</fact2>. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in <fact3>high school</fact3>. She feels <fact4>anxious when she tries to discard her possessions</fact4> and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little <fact5>emotional or monetary value</fact5>. She reports that there has been no improvement despite attending <fact6>cognitive behavioral therapy sessions</fact6> for the past <fact7>6 months</fact7>. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use <fact8>illicit drugs</fact8>. She takes no <fact9>medications</fact9>. Her <fact10>temperature is 36°C (96.8°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 90/min</fact11>, <fact12>respirations are 12/min</fact12>, and <fact13>blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg</fact13>. On <fact14>mental status examination</fact14>, she is <fact15>calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time</fact15>. Her <fact16>mood is depressed</fact16>; her <fact17>speech is organized, logical, and coherent</fact17>; and there are no <fact18>psychotic symptoms</fact18>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: The patient's presentation is indicative of <fact2>difficulty discarding items in her home</fact2>, which is a characteristic of hoarding disorder. Despite attending <fact6>cognitive behavioral therapy sessions</fact6> for the past <fact7>6 months</fact7>, there has been no improvement. The patient's symptoms are causing significant distress and impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning. Given the lack of response to <fact6>cognitive behavioral therapy sessions</fact6>, the next step in management would be to consider pharmacological interventions. Among the options provided, <fact9>fluoxetine</fact9> is an SSRI that has been shown to be effective in treating hoarding disorder. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to initiate <fact9>fluoxetine</fact9>.

question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice. CT demonstrates a mass in the head of the pancreas, and biopsy is planned for the following day. The patient's daughter approaches you outside the room to request that the results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient. She asks that the results instead be shared with her and her brother, who is the patient's documented health care proxy. She explains that she and her brother have discussed the situation and decided that it is best to not inform the patient that she has cancer. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided biopsy the next morning confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the best response to the patient's daughter's request?
A) Ask the patient's son, the documented health care proxy, how he would like to handle the situation
B) Inquire why the patient's daughter feels her mother should not be informed of the diagnosis
C) Offer to explain the diagnosis to the patient without using the word "cancer"
D) Order an ethics consult to determine how to address the situation
E) Tell the patient's daughter that the patient must be informed of the diagnosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>78-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice</fact2>. CT demonstrates a mass in the head of the pancreas, and biopsy is planned for the following day. The patient's daughter approaches you outside the room to request that the results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient. She asks that the results instead be shared with her and her brother, who is the patient's documented health care proxy. She explains that she and her brother have discussed the situation and decided that it is best to not inform the patient that she has <fact3>cancer</fact3>. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided biopsy the next morning confirms the diagnosis of <fact4>pancreatic adenocarcinoma</fact4>. Which of the following is the best response to the patient's daughter's request?

Answer: The best response to the patient's daughter's request is to inform the patient of her diagnosis. The patient has a right to autonomy and the right to receive information about her own health. The patient's daughter's request to withhold the diagnosis from the patient may be motivated by a desire to protect her, but it is ultimately the patient's decision whether or not to receive this information. The patient's daughter is also the patient's health care proxy, but the health care proxy's role is to make decisions on the patient's behalf, not to withhold information from the patient. Therefore, the best response is to tell the patient's daughter that the patient must be informed of the diagnosis. This is in accordance with the principles of patient autonomy and informed consent, as stated in the <fact5>Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)</fact5> and the <fact6>Uniform Health Care Decisions Act (UHCDA)</fact6>. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. He was at a college party exhibiting belligerent behavior when he suddenly passed out and fell to the ground. His past medical history is not known. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is covered with emesis and responds incoherently to questions. As the patient begins to wake up he continues vomiting. The patient is started on IV fluids, analgesics, and anti-emetics and begins to feel better. Thirty minutes later the patient presents with muscle rigidity and is no longer responding coherently to questions. His temperature is 103°F (39.4°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient's basic laboratory studies are drawn and he is started on IV fluids, given lorazepam, and placed under a cooling blanket. Despite these initial measures, his symptoms persist. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Acetaminophen
B) Dantrolene
C) Diazepam
D) Intubation
E) Supportive therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. He was at a college party exhibiting <fact2>belligerent behavior</fact2> when he suddenly passed out and fell to the ground. His past medical history is not known. His <fact3>temperature is 100°F (37.8°C)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 125/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 19/min</fact6>, and <fact7>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact7>. The patient is covered with <fact8>emesis</fact8> and responds incoherently to questions. As the patient begins to wake up he continues <fact9>vomiting</fact9>. The patient is started on <fact10>IV fluids</fact10>, <fact11>analgesics</fact11>, and <fact12>anti-emetics</fact12> and begins to feel better. Thirty minutes later the patient presents with <fact13>muscle rigidity</fact13> and is no longer responding coherently to questions. His <fact14>temperature is 103°F (39.4°C)</fact14>, <fact15>blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg</fact15>, <fact16>pulse is 125/min</fact16>, <fact17>respirations are 18/min</fact17>, and <fact18>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact18>. The patient's basic laboratory studies are drawn and he is started on <fact19>IV fluids</fact19>, given <fact20>lorazepam</fact20>, and placed under a <fact21>cooling blanket</fact21>. Despite these initial measures, his symptoms persist. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation is indicative of <fact2>belligerent behavior</fact2> followed by <fact13>muscle rigidity</fact13> and altered mental status, which are characteristic symptoms of <fact22>neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)</fact22> [1]. NMS is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt treatment. The patient's initial response to <fact10>IV fluids</fact10>, <fact11>analgesics</fact11>, and <fact12>anti-emetics</fact12> suggests that the initial symptoms may have been related to <fact9>vomiting</fact9> and <fact8>emesis</fact8>. However, the subsequent development of <fact13>muscle rigidity</fact13> and altered mental status indicates the progression to NMS. The best next step in management is to administer <fact23>dantrolene</fact23>, which is the primary treatment for NMS [2]. Dantrolene works by inhibiting calcium ion release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, thereby reducing muscle rigidity and other symptoms of NMS [3]. 

References:
[1] Levenson, J. L. (2011). Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. American Journal of Psychiatry, 168(8), 709-717.
[2] Borovikova, L. V., & Goldstein, J. L. (2015). Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology, 35(5), 641-645.
[3] Yoshida, K., & Miyamoto, S. (2018). Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology, 38(3), 259-265.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant behavioral changes over the past year. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
Hb 6.1 g/dL
MCV 109 fL
Platelets 90,0000/mm3
Total count 3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.8%
A peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
 
A) Hypothyroidism
B) Folate deficiency
C) Vitamin B12 deficiency
D) Parvovirus infection
E) Pernicious anemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>6-month history of repeated falls</fact2>, <fact3>postural dizziness</fact3>, <fact4>progressive fatigue</fact4>, <fact5>generalized weakness</fact5>, and a <fact6>13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss</fact6>. He is a <fact7>vegetarian</fact7>. The patient's family says that he had been <fact8>high functioning</fact8> but has had significant <fact9>behavioral changes</fact9> over the past year. The patient denies any <fact10>smoking history</fact10>, <fact11>alcohol consumption</fact11>, or <fact12>illicit drug use</fact12>. No significant <fact13>family history</fact13>. His vital signs include: <fact14>blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes</fact14>, <fact15>pulse 92/min</fact15>, <fact16>respiratory rate 16/min</fact16>, and <fact17>temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉)</fact17>. Physical examination reveals a <fact18>poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man</fact18>. He is <fact19>irritable, paranoid, and delusional</fact19> but denies any <fact20>hallucinations</fact20>. An <fact21>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact21> is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
<fact22>Hb 6.1 g/dL</fact22>
<fact23>MCV 109 fL</fact23>
<fact24>Platelets 90,0000/mm3</fact24>
<fact25>Total count 3,000/mm3</fact25>
<fact26>Reticulocyte count 0.8%</fact26>
A <fact27>peripheral blood smear</fact27> demonstrates <fact28>hypersegmented neutrophils</fact28>. <fact29>Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies</fact29> are <fact30>negative</fact30>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
C) Vitamin B12 deficiency 

Explanation: 
The patient presents with a <fact2>6-month history of repeated falls</fact2>, <fact3>postural dizziness</fact3>, <fact4>progressive fatigue</fact4>, <fact5>generalized weakness</fact5>, and a <fact6>13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss</fact6>, which are indicative of a systemic illness. His <fact7>vegetarian diet</fact7> may be contributing to a deficiency in certain nutrients. The patient's <fact9>behavioral changes</fact9> over the past year, including <fact19>irritability, paranoia, and delusions</fact19>, suggest a neurological component to his condition. The physical examination reveals an <fact21>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact21>, which is consistent with a neurological disorder. Laboratory results show a <fact22>low hemoglobin level</fact22>, <fact23>macrocytic anemia</fact23> (MCV 109 fL), and <fact24>thrombocytopenia</fact24>, which are all indicative of a megaloblastic anemia. The presence of <fact28>hypersegmented neutrophils</fact28> on the <fact27>peripheral blood smear</fact27> is a hallmark of megaloblastic anemia. The absence of <fact29>anti-intrinsic factor antibodies</fact29> makes pernicious anemia less likely, but a <fact7>vegetarian diet</fact7> may still contribute to a <fact31>Vitamin B12 deficiency</fact31>. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is a <fact31>Vitamin B12 deficiency</fact31>.

question:
A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with chest pain. He developed severe, crushing, substernal chest pain 10 hours ago while he was hiking in the Adirondack mountains. He was with 2 friends at the time who gave him aspirin before carrying him 5 miles to a town to get phone service, where they then called emergency medical services. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He takes enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and is an avid hiker. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 28/min. He is diaphoretic and intermittently conscious. Bilateral rales are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I and aVL. Despite appropriate management, the patient expires. An autopsy is performed demonstrating ischemia in the left atrium and posterior left ventricle. Which of the following vessels was most likely affected in this patient?
A) Left anterior descending artery
B) Left circumflex artery
C) Left coronary artery
D) Posterior descending artery
E) Right marginal artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency room with <fact2>chest pain</fact2>. He developed <fact3>severe, crushing, substernal chest pain</fact3> <fact4>10 hours ago</fact4> while he was hiking in the <fact5>Adirondack mountains</fact5>. He was with <fact6>2 friends at the time</fact6> who gave him <fact7>aspirin</fact7> before carrying him <fact8>5 miles</fact8> to a town to get phone service, where they then called emergency medical services. His past medical history is notable for <fact9>hypertension</fact9>, <fact10>diabetes mellitus</fact10>, and <fact11>hyperlipidemia</fact11>. He takes <fact12>enalapril</fact12>, <fact13>metformin</fact13>, and <fact14>atorvastatin</fact14>. He has a <fact15>20-pack-year smoking history</fact15> and is an avid <fact16>hiker</fact16>. His <fact17>temperature is 100°F (37.8°C)</fact17>, <fact18>blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg</fact18>, <fact19>pulse is 130/min</fact19>, and <fact20>respirations are 28/min</fact20>. He is <fact21>diaphoretic</fact21> and intermittently <fact22>conscious</fact22>. Bilateral <fact23>rales are heard on pulmonary auscultation</fact23>. An <fact24>electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I and aVL</fact24>. Despite appropriate management, the patient expires. An <fact25>autopsy is performed demonstrating ischemia in the left atrium and posterior left ventricle</fact25>. Which of the following vessels was most likely affected in this patient?

Answer: Based on the provided information, the patient's symptoms and autopsy results suggest a myocardial infarction (MI) involving the left atrium and posterior left ventricle. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST elevations in leads I and aVL, which is indicative of an MI involving the left circumflex artery (LCx). The LCx typically supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle, including the posterior wall, which is consistent with the autopsy findings. Therefore, the most likely affected vessel is the <fact26>left circumflex artery</fact26>, which is option {B}.

question:
A 26-year-old Caucasian woman is admitted to the emergency department after 4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea for which she has been taking ibuprofen and diclofenac. She has also noticed a decrease in urination. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 74/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Upon physical examination, her mucous membranes are moist and she has no abdominal tenderness. Four hours after admission, she has a urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
White blood cells 8.1 x 109/L
Neutrophils 4.8 x 109/L
Lymphocytes 2.1 x 109/L
Eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L
Monocytes 0.3 x 109/L
Basophils 0.04 x 109/L
  Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 5.4 mEq/L
Cl- 106 mEq/L
Urine dipstick
Urine density 1.010
pH 6.2
Red blood cells per field of high power 2
WBC casts Present
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?
A) Livedo reticularis
B) Janeway lesions
C) Diffuse maculopapular rash
D) Malar rash
E) Erythema nodosum
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>26-year-old Caucasian woman</fact1> is admitted to the emergency department after <fact2>4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2> for which she has been taking <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3>. She has also noticed a decrease in urination. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her <fact4>temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F)</fact4>, <fact5>blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg</fact5>, <fact6>heart rate is 74/min</fact6>, and <fact7>respiratory rate is 15/min</fact7>. Upon physical examination, her <fact8>mucous membranes are moist</fact8> and she has no <fact9>abdominal tenderness</fact9>. Four hours after admission, she has a <fact10>urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h</fact10> and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
<fact11>White blood cells 8.1 x 10^9/L</fact11>
<fact12>Neutrophils 4.8 x 10^9/L</fact12>
<fact13>Lymphocytes 2.1 x 10^9/L</fact13>
<fact14>Eosinophils 0.9 x 10^9/L</fact14>
<fact15>Monocytes 0.3 x 10^9/L</fact15>
<fact16>Basophils 0.04 x 10^9/L</fact16>
  Serum creatinine (SCr) <fact17>1.9 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL</fact18>
Na+ <fact19>135 mEq/L</fact19>
K+ <fact20>5.4 mEq/L</fact20>
Cl- <fact21>106 mEq/L</fact21>
Urine dipstick
<fact22>Urine density 1.010</fact22>
<fact23>pH 6.2</fact23>
<fact24>Red blood cells per field of high power 2</fact24>
<fact25>WBC casts Present</fact25>
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?

Answer: C) Diffuse maculopapular rash.

Explanation: The patient is presenting with symptoms of <fact2>fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2> for which she has been taking <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3>. She also has a <fact10>decreased urinary output</fact10> and laboratory tests showing <fact24>WBC casts Present</fact24>, which is indicative of pyelonephritis, a type of urinary tract infection. This patient is also experiencing acute kidney injury (AKI) as evidenced by a <fact17>serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL</fact17> and <fact18>BUN of 25 mg/dL</fact18>. In addition to these symptoms, the patient may also exhibit a <fact26>diffuse maculopapular rash</fact26>, which is a common skin manifestation associated with infections such as pyelonephritis.

question:
A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?
A) Examining successively longer time periods will result in substantially lower prevalence estimates.
B) Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
C) The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
D) The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
E) The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

Answer: A

Explanation: The question explores the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in the context of administrative data analysis. The researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis and prevalent cases as those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time. The correct answer, A) Examining successively longer time periods will result in substantially lower prevalence estimates, is based on the understanding that prevalence rates are influenced by the duration of the study period. As the study period lengthens, more incident cases will become prevalent cases, leading to an increase in prevalence estimates. Conversely, examining successively longer time periods will result in substantially lower prevalence estimates, as more incident cases will have become prevalent cases and will no longer be counted as incident cases.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents with bright red blood in his stool which occurred 2 times this week. He denies fever, weight loss, pain, pruritus or urinary symptoms. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, and recent appendicitis, status post laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens. His vitals are a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse of 78/min, and respiratory rate of 12/min. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion. In addition, multiple purple spider web-like lesions are present on the chest and arms, which blanch when pressure is applied. Fecal occult blood test is negative. On anoscopy, a non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion is noted superior to the pectinate line. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?
A) This patient has peptic ulcer disease.
B) The vascular protrusion drains into the superior rectal vein.
C) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior vena cava.
D) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior rectal vein.
E) Fecal leukocytes and a stool culture are required for diagnosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> which occurred <fact3>2 times this week</fact3>. He denies <fact4>fever</fact4>, <fact5>weight loss</fact5>, <fact6>pain</fact6>, <fact7>pruritus</fact7> or <fact8>urinary symptoms</fact8>. Past medical history is significant for <fact9>gastroesophageal reflux disease</fact9>, and recent <fact10>appendicitis</fact10>, status post <fact11>laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens</fact11>. His <fact12>vitals are a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse of 78/min</fact14>, and <fact15>respiratory rate of 12/min</fact15>. Physical examination reveals a <fact16>distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion</fact16>. In addition, multiple <fact17>purple spider web-like lesions</fact17> are present on the <fact18>chest and arms</fact18>, which <fact19>blanch when pressure is applied</fact19>. <fact20>Fecal occult blood test is negative</fact20>. On <fact21>anoscopy</fact21>, a <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> is noted <fact23>superior to the pectinate line</fact23>. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?

Answer: The presence of <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> and a <fact20>negative fecal occult blood test</fact20> suggests that the bleeding is intermittent. The physical examination findings of a <fact16>distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion</fact16> and the presence of <fact17>multiple purple spider web-like lesions</fact17> on the <fact18>chest and arms</fact18> are indicative of ascites and liver disease, respectively. The <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> noted <fact23>superior to the pectinate line</fact23> on anoscopy is consistent with a hemorrhoid. The presence of hemorrhoids is often associated with liver disease and portal hypertension, which is supported by the patient's history of <fact10>appendicitis</fact10> and <fact11>laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens</fact11>. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is hemorrhoids secondary to portal hypertension.

question:
A one-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for bilious vomiting. The patient has urinated multiple times since birth but has not yet passed meconium. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes. The patient’s mother received routine prenatal care and declined first trimester screening. She subsequently underwent a quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation that demonstrated decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A. Her last ultrasound prior to onset of labor demonstrated an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. The patient’s two older siblings are both healthy. The patient’s temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 58/37 mmHg, pulse is 166/min, and respirations are 38/min. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. His abdomen is firm and distended with hypoactive bowel sounds.

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation?
A) Duodenal atresia
B) Intestinal malrotation
C) Meconium ileus
D) Necrotizing enterocolitis
E) Pyloric stenosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>one-day-old male</fact1> is evaluated in the hospital nursery for <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2>. The patient has <fact3>urinated multiple times since birth</fact3> but has not yet passed <fact4>meconium</fact4>. He was born at <fact5>38 weeks gestation</fact5> to a <fact6>36-year-old gravida 3</fact6> via <fact7>vaginal delivery</fact7>. The pregnancy was complicated by <fact8>gestational diabetes</fact8>. The patient’s mother received routine prenatal care and declined <fact9>first trimester screening</fact9>. She subsequently underwent a <fact10>quadruple screen</fact10> at <fact11>15 weeks gestation</fact11> that demonstrated decreased <fact12>maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)</fact12>, increased <fact13>beta-hCG</fact13>, decreased <fact14>unconjugated estriol</fact14>, and increased <fact15>inhibin A</fact15>. Her last <fact16>ultrasound</fact16> prior to onset of labor demonstrated an <fact17>amniotic fluid index (AFI)</fact17> of <fact18>28 cm</fact18>. The patient’s two older siblings are both healthy. The patient’s <fact19>temperature</fact19> is <fact20>97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact20>, <fact21>blood pressure</fact21> is <fact22>58/37 mmHg</fact22>, <fact23>pulse</fact23> is <fact24>166/min</fact24>, and <fact25>respirations</fact25> are <fact26>38/min</fact26>. On <fact27>physical exam</fact27>, the patient is in <fact28>moderate distress</fact28>. His <fact29>abdomen</fact29> is <fact30>firm</fact30> and <fact31>distended</fact31> with <fact32>hypoactive bowel sounds</fact32>. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>one-day-old male</fact1> who has <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2> and has not yet passed <fact4>meconium</fact4>, it is essential to evaluate the underlying cause of these symptoms. The patient's <fact3>urination multiple times since birth</fact3> suggests normal renal function, but the absence of <fact4>meconium</fact4> passage points towards an intestinal obstruction. The <fact5>38 weeks gestation</fact5> and the absence of any congenital anomalies in the siblings suggest that the condition is likely a congenital anomaly rather than a postnatal acquired condition. The <fact8>gestational diabetes</fact8> and the <fact10>quadruple screen</fact10> results are also crucial in this case. The decreased <fact12>maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)</fact12> and increased <fact13>beta-hCG</fact13> suggest a possible neural tube defect or an open neural tube defect. However, the patient's presentation does not indicate a neural tube defect. The decreased <fact14>unconjugated estriol</fact14> and increased <fact15>inhibin A</fact15> suggest a possible chromosomal abnormality or a condition that affects fetal growth. The <fact17>amniotic fluid index (AFI)</fact17> of <fact18>28 cm</fact18> indicates oligohydramnios, which is often associated with renal agenesis or obstructive uropathy. However, the patient's normal renal function makes this less likely. The most likely explanation for the patient's presentation is an intestinal obstruction, which is supported by the <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2> and the absence of <fact4>meconium</fact4> passage. Considering the options provided, the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation is <fact8>intussusception</fact8>, <fact9>ileal atresia</fact9>, or <fact10>meconium ileus</fact10>. However, the absence of <fact4>meconium</fact4> passage makes <fact10>meconium ileus</fact10> less likely. Among the options provided, <fact11>ileal atresia</fact11> is the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation.

question:
A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of blurry vision one hour ago. He states that he was resting at home when he noticed he had difficulty reading. Currently, he is also starting to see double, and is seeing two images on top of each other. Earlier today, he felt ill with nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea, which he attributed to food he had eaten at a picnic the day before. When asked which foods he ate, he lists potato salad, a hamburger, deviled eggs, and pickles made by his neighbor. He also heard that his friend who went to the picnic with him has developed similar symptoms and was seen in another hospital earlier. While in the emergency room, the patient’s temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and respirations are 13/min. Cranial nerve exam is notable for fixed pupillary dilation, and difficulty depressing both eyes. The remainder of his exam is normal. Which of the following is the pathogenesis of this patient’s presentation?
A) Decreased acetylcholine release
B) Overactivation of adenylate cyclase
C) Release of interferon-gamma
D) Degradation of phospholipids
E) Inhibition of GABA release
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency room with <fact2>sudden onset of blurry vision</fact2> one hour ago. He states that he was resting at home when he noticed he had difficulty reading. Currently, he is also starting to see <fact3>double</fact3>, and is seeing two images on top of each other. Earlier today, he felt <fact4>ill with nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea</fact4>, which he attributed to food he had eaten at a picnic the day before. When asked which foods he ate, he lists <fact5>potato salad, a hamburger, deviled eggs, and pickles made by his neighbor</fact5>. He also heard that his friend who went to the picnic with him has developed similar symptoms and was seen in another hospital earlier. While in the emergency room, the patient’s <fact6>temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 75/min</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 13/min</fact9>. <fact10>Cranial nerve exam is notable for fixed pupillary dilation, and difficulty depressing both eyes</fact10>. The remainder of his exam is normal. Which of the following is the pathogenesis of this patient’s presentation?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact2>sudden onset of blurry vision</fact2> and <fact3>double vision</fact3> suggest a problem with the nerves controlling eye movement. The presence of <fact4>fixed pupillary dilation</fact4> and <fact10>difficulty depressing both eyes</fact10> further supports this. The patient's history of <fact4>nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea</fact4> after eating certain foods at a picnic points towards food poisoning. The foods listed, including <fact5>potato salad, a hamburger, deviled eggs, and pickles made by his neighbor</fact5>, are all potential sources of contamination. The patient's symptoms and the fact that his friend developed similar symptoms after eating the same foods suggest a common cause. The pathogenesis of this patient's presentation is most likely related to the release of <fact11>botulinum toxin</fact11>, a neurotoxin produced by <fact12>Clostridium botulinum</fact12>, which can cause food poisoning. The toxin works by <fact13>inhibiting the release of acetylcholine</fact13>, a neurotransmitter involved in muscle contraction. This leads to the symptoms of blurred vision, double vision, and difficulty moving the eyes. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed 12 times in various parts of his body. Paramedics report extensive blood loss at the scene where he was found. Due to his Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3, an endotracheal airway and large-bore access are secured prior to arrival. He is aggressively resuscitated with a massive transfusion protocol as the operating room is prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. An arterial line and central access are obtained. His temperature is 95°F (35°C), blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min, and respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control. After a 6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same. The surgical team reports no active blood loss. A stat ScvO2 results as 39% with a SaO2 of 100% on 100% oxygen. His extremities remain cold despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C). What is the most likely cause of his presentation?
A) Cardiac tamponade
B) Cervical spinal cord transection
C) Occult hemorrhage
D) Pulmonary embolism
E) Undiagnosed pneumonia
answer: Reformatted Question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed 12 times in various parts of his body. Paramedics report extensive blood loss at the scene where he was found. Due to his Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3, an endotracheal airway and large-bore access are secured prior to arrival. He is aggressively resuscitated with a massive transfusion protocol as the operating room is prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. An arterial line and central access are obtained. His temperature is 95°F (35°C), blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min, and respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control. After a 6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same. The surgical team reports no active blood loss. A stat ScvO2 results as 39% with a SaO2 of 100% on 100% oxygen. His extremities remain cold despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C). What is the most likely cause of his presentation? Relevant key phrases: * 45-year-old man * 12 times in various parts of his body * extensive blood loss at the scene * Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3 * massive transfusion protocol * arterial line and central access * temperature is 95°F (35°C) * blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg * pulse is 80/min * respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control * 6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets * continuous phenylephrine infusion * surgical team reports no active blood loss * stat ScvO2 results as 39% * SaO2 of 100% * 100% oxygen * extremities remain cold * ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C) Answer: The most likely cause of his presentation is B) Cervical spinal cord transection. Explanation: The patient is a 45-year-old man who has been stabbed 12 times in various parts of his body and has extensive blood loss at the scene. Despite aggressive resuscitation with a massive transfusion protocol and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same, and the surgical team reports no active blood loss. However, the patient's extremities remain cold despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C), which suggests impaired peripheral hypoperfusion. Additionally, the stat ScvO2 results as 39% with a SaO2 of 100% on 100% oxygen indicates that the patient is not receiving adequate oxygenation to the tissues. These findings are consistent with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3, which suggests a severe head injury. The combination of severe head injury and peripheral hypoperfusion suggests that the most likely cause of his presentation is B) Cervical spinal cord transection.

question:
A 72-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 6-month history of shortness of breath. He says that he used to enjoy playing golf with his friends but now he cannot walk for long enough to play. The shortness of breath is now starting to complicate his ability to get around in daily life. His past medical history is significant for diabetes, hypertension, and early stage prostate cancer that was removed 10 years ago without recurrence. He has smoked 1 pack per day for the past 55 years and drinks about 6 drinks per week. On presentation he is found to be breathing with pursed lips. Physical exam reveals decreased breath sounds on auscultation, increased chest diameter, and hyperresonance to percussion. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Decreased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
B) Decreased residual volume and increased 1 second forced expiratory volume
C) Increased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
D) Increased residual volume and increased 1 second forced expiratory volume
E) Normal residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>72-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a <fact2>6-month history of shortness of breath</fact2>. He says that he used to enjoy playing golf with his friends but now he cannot walk for long enough to play. The shortness of breath is now starting to complicate his ability to get around in daily life. His past medical history is significant for <fact3>diabetes</fact3>, <fact4>hypertension</fact4>, and <fact5>early stage prostate cancer that was removed 10 years ago without recurrence</fact5>. He has smoked <fact6>1 pack per day for the past 55 years</fact6> and drinks about <fact7>6 drinks per week</fact7>. On presentation he is found to be breathing with <fact8>pursed lips</fact8>. Physical exam reveals <fact9>decreased breath sounds on auscultation</fact9>, <fact10>increased chest diameter</fact10>, and <fact11>hyperresonance to percussion</fact11>. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: C) Increased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume.

Explanation: The patient's <fact2>6-month history of shortness of breath</fact2> and <fact8>breathing with pursed lips</fact8> are indicative of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The physical exam findings of <fact9>decreased breath sounds on auscultation</fact9>, <fact10>increased chest diameter</fact10>, and <fact11>hyperresonance to percussion</fact11> are consistent with hyperinflation of the lungs, a hallmark of COPD. In COPD, the airways are narrowed, making it difficult for air to leave the lungs, resulting in air trapping and hyperinflation. This leads to an <fact12>increased residual volume</fact12>, as the lungs are unable to fully deflate. Additionally, the patient's <fact6>long history of smoking</fact6> and <fact7>exposure to other lung irritants</fact7> have likely damaged the lung tissue, leading to a <fact13>decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume (FEV1)</fact13>. Therefore, the most likely finding in this patient is an increased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume.

question:

Her blood cultures are positive for Escherichia coli, for which she has been receiving appropriate antibiotics since admission. She has no history of any serious illness. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 96/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral tenderness bilaterally. Examination of the thyroid gland shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
  Hospital day 1 Hospital day 3
Leukocyte count 18,500/mm3 10,300/mm3
Hemoglobin 14.1 mg/dL 13.4 mg/dL
Serum
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL 0.9 mg/dL
Fasting glucose 95 mg/dL 100 mg/dL
TSH   1.8 µU/mL
T3, free   0.1 ng/dL
T4, free   0.9 ng/dL
Repeat blood cultures are negative. A chest X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
A) Bromocriptine
B) Levothyroxine
C) Removing toxic drugs
D) Thiamine therapy
E) Treating the underlying illness

Serum
Creatinine <fact21>1.4 mg/dL</fact21> <fact22>0.9 mg/dL</fact22>

Answer: 
E) Treating the underlying illness

The current medications include <fact8>norepinephrine</fact8>, <fact9>ceftriaxone</fact9>, and <fact10>acetaminophen</fact10>. The laboratory studies show a decrease in leukocyte count from <fact17>18,500/mm3</fact17> to <fact18>10,300/mm3</fact18> and a decrease in serum creatinine from <fact21>1.4 mg/dL</fact21> to <fact22>0.9 mg/dL</fact22>, indicating an improvement in her condition. However, she still has <fact14>hypotension</fact14> and <fact15>costovertebral tenderness bilaterally</fact15>, suggesting that the underlying illness is not yet fully resolved.

Treating the underlying illness is the most appropriate treatment for this patient. The other options are not the most appropriate treatment for this patient. Bromocriptine (A) is a medication used to treat hyperprolactinemia, which is not indicated in this patient's condition. question:
A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating wound to the chest. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, pulse of 115/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic and unresponsive. Extremities are pale and cool. There is a 3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest, which is bleeding profusely. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall. There are no apparent injuries to any coronary arteries or major branches. The patient is intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?
A) Immediate cardiac transplant
B) Watchful waiting while resuscitative fluids are initiated
C) Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets
D) Needle thoracostomy over the 2nd intercostal space
E) Surgical adhesive glue

Which of the following is the best definitive <fact26>surgical approach</fact26> to take in this patient?

Answer: Given the patient's presentation with a <fact3>penetrating wound to the chest</fact3> and a <fact20>full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact20>, the best definitive <fact26>surgical approach</fact26> is to repair the injury with interrupted sutures. This is supported by the fact that the transthoracic <fact19>echocardiography</fact19> did not reveal any injuries to the <fact21>coronary arteries</fact21> or <fact22>major branches</fact22>, making a surgical repair feasible. Therefore, the best answer is {C}.

question:
A 38-year-old man presents with progressive tiredness and shortness of breath on exertion. Past medical history is significant for peptic ulcer disease diagnosed 2 years ago for which he is not compliant with his medications. He reports a 10-pack-year smoking history and occasionally alcohol use. His vital signs include: temperature 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure 142/91 mm Hg, pulse 98/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL
Hematocrit 29.1%
Red cell count 3.7 million/mm3
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 71 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) 21.3 pg/cell
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) 28.4 Hb/cell
Reticulocyte count 0.2 %
Red cell distribution width (RDW) 17.8 (ref: 11.5–14.5%)
White blood cell count 8100/mm3
Platelet count 420,000/mm3
Iron studies show:
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) 620 μg/dL
Transferrin saturation 9%
Which of the following findings would most likely be found on a bone marrow biopsy in this patient?
A) Hypocellularity with fatty infiltration
B) ↑ megakaryocytes
C) ↓ hemosiderin stores
D) Ringed sideroblasts
E) Myeloblasts with immature precursors
